text: PREFACE.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (1)Men would never be superstitious, if they could govern all their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: circumstances by set rules, or if they were always favoured by fortune: but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being frequently driven into straits where rules are useless, and being
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: often kept fluctuating pitiably between hope and fear by the uncertainty
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of fortune's greedily coveted favours, they are consequently, for the most
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: part, very prone to credulity. (2) The human mind is readily swayed this way
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or that in times of doubt, especially when hope and fear are struggling for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mastery, though usually it is boastful, over - confident, and vain.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (3) This as a general fact I suppose everyone knows, though few, I believe,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: know their own nature; no one can have lived in the world without observing
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that most people, when in prosperity, are so over-brimming with wisdom
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (however inexperienced they may be), that they take every offer of advice as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a personal insult, whereas in adversity they know not where to turn, but beg
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and pray for counsel from every passer-by. (4) No plan is then too futile,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: too absurd, or too fatuous for their adoption; the most frivolous causes
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will raise them to hope, or plunge them into despair - if anything happens
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: during their fright which reminds them of some past good or ill, they think
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it portends a happy or unhappy issue, and therefore (though it may have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proved abortive a hundred times before) style it a lucky or unlucky omen.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (5) Anything which excites their astonishment they believe to be a portent
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: signifying the anger of the gods or of the Supreme Being, and, mistaking
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: superstition for religion, account it impious not to avert the evil with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prayer and sacrifice. (6) Signs and wonders of this sort they conjure up
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perpetually, till one might think Nature as mad as themselves, they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interpret her so fantastically.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (7) Thus it is brought prominently before us, that superstition's chief
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: victims are those persons who greedily covet temporal advantages; they it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is, who (especially when they are in danger, and cannot help themselves) are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wont with Prayers and womanish tears to implore help from God: upbraiding
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Reason as blind, because she cannot show a sure path to the shadows they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pursue, and rejecting human wisdom as vain; but believing the phantoms of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagination, dreams, and other childish absurdities, to be the very oracles
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Heaven. (8) As though God had turned away from the wise, and written His
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: decrees, not in the mind of man but in the entrails of beasts, or left them
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be proclaimed by the inspiration and instinct of fools, madmen, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: birds. Such is the unreason to which terror can drive mankind!
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (9) Superstition, then, is engendered, preserved, and fostered by fear. If
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anyone desire an example, let him take Alexander, who only began
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fortune in the passes of Sysis (Curtius, v. 4); whereas after he had
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conquered Darius he consulted prophets no more, till a second time
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: frightened by reverses. (10) When the Scythians were provoking a battle, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with sacrificed victims." (11) Very numerous examples of a like nature might
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be cited, clearly showing the fact, that only while under the dominion of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear do men fall a prey to superstition; that all the portents ever invested
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the reverence of misguided religion are mere phantoms of dejected and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fearful minds; and lastly, that prophets have most power among the people,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and are most formidable to rulers, precisely at those times when the state
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is in most peril. (12) I think this is sufficiently plain to all, and will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore say no more on the subject.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (13) The origin of superstition above given affords us a clear reason for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the fact, that it comes to all men naturally, though some refer its rise to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a dim notion of God, universal to mankind, and also tends to show, that it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is no less inconsistent and variable than other mental hallucinations and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand how difficult it is, to maintain in the same course men prone to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: about the same pitch of misery, it never assents long to any one remedy, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is always best pleased by a novelty which has not yet proved illusive.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been taken to counteract this evil by investing religion, whether true or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: false, with such pomp and ceremony, that it may rise superior to every
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: scorn, and to preach only novelties and paradoxes, such as would tickle
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the ears of their congregation. (28) This state of things necessarily
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stirred up an amount of controversy, envy, and hatred, which no lapse of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: time could appease; so that we can scarcely wonder that of the old religion
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing survives but its outward forms (even these, in the mouth of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: multitude, seem rather adulation than adoration of the Deity), and that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: faith has become a mere compound of credulity and prejudices - aye,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prejudices too, which degrade man from rational being to beast, which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: completely stifle the power of judgment between true and false, which seem,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in fact, carefully fostered for the purpose of extinguishing the last spark
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of reason! (29) Piety, great God! and religion are become a tissue of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ridiculous mysteries; men, who flatly despise reason, who reject and turn
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: away from understanding as naturally corrupt, these, I say, these of all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men, are thought, 0 lie most horrible! to possess light from on High. (30)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Verily, if they had but one spark of light from on High, they would not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: insolently rave, but would learn to worship God more wisely, and would be as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: marked among their fellows for mercy as they now are for malice; if they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were concerned for their opponents' souls, instead of for their own
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reputations, they would no longer fiercely persecute, but rather be filled
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with pity and compassion.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (31) Furthermore, if any Divine light were in them, it would appear from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their doctrine. (32) I grant that they are never tired of professing their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wonder at the profound mysteries of Holy Writ; still I cannot discover that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they teach anything but speculations of Platonists and Aristotelians, to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which (in order to save their credit for Christianity) they have made Holy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Writ conform; not content to rave with the Greeks themselves, they want to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: make the prophets rave also; showing conclusively, that never even in sleep
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have they caught a glimpse of Scripture's Divine nature. (33) The very
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vehemence of their admiration for the mysteries plainly attests, that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their belief in the Bible is a formal assent rather than a living faith: and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the fact is made still more apparent by their laying down beforehand, as a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foundation for the study and true interpretation of Scripture, the principle
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that it is in every passage true and divine. (34) Such a doctrine should be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reached only after strict scrutiny and thorough comprehension of the Sacred
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Books (which would teach it much better, for they stand in need no human
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: factions), and not be set up on the threshold, as it were, of inquiry.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (35) As I pondered over the facts that the light of reason is not only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: despised, but by many even execrated as a source of impiety, that human
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commentaries are accepted as divine records, and that credulity is extolled
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as faith; as I marked the fierce controversies of philosophers raging in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Church and State, the source of bitter hatred and dissension, the ready
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instruments of sedition and other ills innumerable, I determined to examine
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Bible afresh in a careful, impartial, and unfettered spirit, making no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assumptions concerning it, and attributing to it no doctrines, which I do
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not find clearly therein set down. (36) With these precautions I constructed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a method of Scriptural interpretation, and thus equipped proceeded to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inquire - what is prophecy? (37) In what sense did God reveal himself to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophets, and why were these particular men - chosen by him? (38) Was it on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: account of the sublimity of their thoughts about the Deity and nature, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was it solely on account of their piety? (39) These questions being
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: answered, I was easily able to conclude, that the authority of the prophets
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has weight only in matters of morality, and that their speculative doctrines
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affect us little.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (40) Next I inquired, why the Hebrews were called God's chosen people, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: discovering that it was only because God had chosen for them a certain strip
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of territory, where they might live peaceably and at ease, I learnt that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Law revealed by God to Moses was merely the law of the individual Hebrew
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state, therefore that it was binding on none but Hebrews, and not even
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on Hebrews after the downfall of their nation. (41) Further, in order to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ascertain, whether it could be concluded from Scripture, that the human
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding standing is naturally corrupt, I inquired whether the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Universal Religion, the Divine Law revealed through the Prophets and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Apostles to the whole human race, differs from that which is taught by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: light of natural reason, whether miracles can take place in violation of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws of nature, and if so, whether they imply the existence of God more
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: surely and clearly than events, which we understand plainly and distinctly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through their immediate natural causes.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (42) Now, as in the whole course of my investigation I found nothing taught
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: expressly by Scripture, which does not agree with our understanding, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which is repugnant thereto, and as I saw that the prophets taught nothing,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which is not very simple and easily to be grasped by all, and further, that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they clothed their leaching in the style, and confirmed it with the reasons,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which would most deeply move the mind of the masses to devotion towards God,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I became thoroughly convinced, that the Bible leaves reason absolutely free,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that it has nothing in common with philosophy, in fact, that Revelation and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Philosophy stand on different footings. In order to set this forth
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: categorically and exhaust the whole question, I point out the way in which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Bible should be interpreted, and show that all of spiritual questions
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should be sought from it alone, and not from the objects of ordinary
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge. (43) Thence I pass on to indicate the false notions, which have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the fact that the multitude - ever prone to superstition, and caring
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more for the shreds of antiquity for eternal truths - pays homage to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Books of the Bible, rather than to the Word of God. (44) I show that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Word of God has not been revealed as a certain number of books, was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: displayed to the prophets as a simple idea of the mind, namely, obedience to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God in singleness of heart, and in the practice of justice and charity; and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I further point out, that this doctrine is set forth in Scripture in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accordance with the opinions and understandings of those, among whom the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Apostles and Prophets preached, to the end that men might receive it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: willingly, and with their whole heart.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (45) Having thus laid bare the bases of belief, I draw the conclusion that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Revelation has obedience for its sole object, therefore, in purpose no less
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than in foundation and method, stands entirely aloof from ordinary
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge; each has its separate province, neither can be called the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: handmaid of the other.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (46) Furthermore, as men's habits of mind differ, so that some more readily
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: embrace one form of faith, some another, for what moves one to pray may move
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another only to scoff, I conclude, in accordance with what has gone before,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that everyone should be free to choose for himself the foundations of his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: creed, and that faith should be judged only by its fruits; each would then
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obey God freely with his whole heart, while nothing would be publicly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: honoured save justice and charity.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (47) Having thus drawn attention to the liberty conceded to everyone by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revealed law of God, I pass on to another part of my subject, and prove that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this same liberty can and should be accorded with safety to the state and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the magisterial authority - in fact, that it cannot be withheld without
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: great danger to peace and detriment to the community.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (48) In order to establish my point, I start from the natural rights of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual, which are co-extensive with his desires and power, and from the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact that no one is bound to live as another pleases, but is the guardian of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his own liberty. (49) I show that these rights can only be transferred to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those whom we depute to defend us, who acquire with the duties of defence
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the power of ordering our lives, and I thence infer that rulers possess
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rights only limited by their power, that they are the sole guardians of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: justice and liberty, and that their subjects should act in all things as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they dictate: nevertheless, since no one can so utterly abdicate his own
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of self-defence as to cease to be a man, I conclude that no one can be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deprived of his natural rights absolutely, but that subjects, either by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: tacit agreement, or by social contract, retain a certain number, which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be taken from them without great danger to the state.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (50) From these considerations I pass on to the Hebrew State, which I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: describe at some length, in order to trace the manner in which Religion
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: acquired the force of law, and to touch on other noteworthy points. (51) I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: then prove, that the holders of sovereign power are the depositories and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interpreters of religious no less than of civil ordinances, and that they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: alone have the right to decide what is just or unjust, pious or impious;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lastly, I conclude by showing, that they best retain this right and secure
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: safety to their state by allowing every man to think what he likes, and say
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what he thinks.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (52) Such, Philosophical Reader, are the questions I submit to your notice,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: counting on your approval, for the subject matter of the whole book and of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the several chapters is important and profitable. (53) I would say more, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I do not want my preface to extend to a volume, especially as I know that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its leading propositions are to Philosophers but common places. (54) To the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest of mankind I care not to commend my treatise, for I cannot expect that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it contains anything to please them: I know how deeply rooted are the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prejudices embraced under the name of religion; I am aware that in the mind
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the masses superstition is no less deeply rooted than fear; I recognize
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that their constancy is mere obstinacy, and that they are led to praise or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blame by impulse rather than reason. (55) Therefore the multitude, and those
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of like passions with the multitude, I ask not to read my book; nay, I would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rather that they should utterly neglect it, than that they should
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: misinterpret it after their wont. (56) They would gain no good themselves,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and might prove a stumbling-block to others, whose philosophy is hampered by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the belief that Reason is a mere handmaid to Theology, and whom I seek in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this work especially to benefit. (57) But as there will be many who have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: neither the leisure, nor, perhaps, the inclination to read through all I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have written, I feel bound here, as at the end of my treatise, to declare
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that I have written nothing, which I do not most willingly submit to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: examination and judgment of my country's rulers, and that I am ready to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: retract anything, which they shall decide to be repugnant to the laws or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prejudicial to the public good. (58) I know that I am a man and, as a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man, liable to error, but against error I have taken scrupulous care, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: striven to keep in entire accordance with the laws of my country, with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: loyalty, and with morality.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: CHAPTER I. - Of Prophecy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (1) Prophecy, or revelation is sure knowledge revealed by God to man. (2) A
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophet is one who interprets the revelations of God {insights} to those who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are unable to attain to sure knowledge of the matters revealed, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore can only apprehend them by simple faith.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (3) The Hebrew word for prophet is "naw-vee'", Strong:5030, [Endnote 1]
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: i.e. speaker or interpreter, but in Scripture its meaning is restricted to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interpreter of God, as we may learn from Exodus vii:1, where God says to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses, "See, I have made thee a god to Pharaoh, and Aaron thy brother shall
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be thy prophet;" implying that, since in interpreting Moses' words to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Pharaoh, Aaron acted the part of a prophet, Moses would be to Pharaoh as a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: god, or in the attitude of a god.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (4) Prophets I will treat of in the next chapter, and at present consider
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophecy.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (5) Now it is evident, from the definition above given, that prophecy really
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: includes ordinary knowledge; for the knowledge which we acquire by our
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural faculties depends on knowledge of God and His eternal laws; but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ordinary knowledge is common to all men as men, and rests on foundations
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which all share, whereas the multitude always strains after rarities
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and exceptions, and thinks little of the gifts of nature; so that, when
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophecy is talked of, ordinary knowledge is not supposed to be included.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (6) Nevertheless it has as much right as any other to be called Divine, for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God's nature, in so far as we share therein, and God's laws, dictate it to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us; nor does it suffer from that to which we give the preeminence, except in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as the latter transcends its limits and cannot be accounted for by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural laws taken in themselves. (7) In respect to the certainty it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involves, and the source from which it is derived, i.e. God, ordinary,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge is no whit inferior to prophetic, unless indeed we believe, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rather dream, that the prophets had human bodies but superhuman minds, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore that their sensations and consciousness were entirely different
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from our own.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (8) But, although ordinary knowledge is Divine, its professors cannot be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called prophets [Endnote 2], for they teach what the rest of mankind could
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perceive and apprehend, not merely by simple faith, but as surely and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: honourably as themselves.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (9) Seeing then that our mind subjectively contains in itself and partakes
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the nature of God, and solely from this cause is enabled to form notions
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explaining natural phenomena and inculcating morality, it follows that we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may rightly assert the nature of the human mind (in so far as it is thus
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived) to be a primary cause of Divine revelation. (10) All that we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: clearly and distinctly understand is dictated to us, as I have just pointed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: out, by the idea and nature of God; not indeed through words, but in a way
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far more excellent and agreeing perfectly with the nature of the mind, as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all who have enjoyed intellectual certainty will doubtless attest. (11)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Here, however, my chief purpose is to speak of matters having reference to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scripture, so these few words on the light of reason will suffice.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (12) I will now pass on to, and treat more fully, the other ways and means
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by which God makes revelations to mankind, both of that which transcends
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ordinary knowledge, and of that within its scope; for there is no reason why
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God should not employ other means to communicate what we know already by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of reason.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (13) Our conclusions on the subject must be drawn solely from Scripture; for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what can we affirm about matters transcending our knowledge except what is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: told us by the words or writings of prophets? (14) And since there are, so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as I know, no prophets now alive, we have no alternative but to read the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: books of prophets departed, taking care the while not to reason from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: metaphor or to ascribe anything to our authors which they do not themselves
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinctly state. (15) I must further premise that the Jews never make any
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mention or account of secondary, or particular causes, but in a spirit of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religion, piety, and what is commonly called godliness, refer all things
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: directly to the Deity. (16) For instance if they make money by a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: transaction, they say God gave it to them; if they desire anything, they say
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God has disposed their hearts towards it; if they think anything, they say
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God told them. (17) Hence we must not suppose that everything is prophecy or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revelation which is described in Scripture as told by God to anyone, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only such things as are expressly announced as prophecy or revelation, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are plainly pointed to as such by the context.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18) A perusal of the sacred books will show us that all God's revelations
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the prophets were made through words or appearances, or a combination of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the two. (19) These words and appearances were of two kinds; 1.- real when
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external to the mind of the prophet who heard or saw them, 2.- imaginary
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when the imagination of the prophet was in a state which led him distinctly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to suppose that he heard or saw them.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20) With a real voice God revealed to Moses the laws which He wished to be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: transmitted to the Hebrews, as we may see from Exodus xxv:22, where God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: says, "And there I will meet with thee and I will commune with thee from the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mercy seat which is between the Cherubim." (21) Some sort of real voice must
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily have been employed, for Moses found God ready to commune with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him at any time. This, as I shall shortly show, is the only instance of a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: real voice.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (22) We might, perhaps, suppose that the voice with which God called Samuel
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was real, for in 1 Sam. iii:21, we read, "And the Lord appeared again in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Shiloh, for the Lord revealed Himself to Samuel in Shiloh by the word of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lord;" implying that the appearance of the Lord consisted in His making
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Himself known to Samuel through a voice; in other words, that Samuel heard
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Lord speaking. (23) But we are compelled to distinguish between the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophecies of Moses and those of other prophets, and therefore must decide
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that this voice was imaginary, a conclusion further supported by the voice's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: resemblance to the voice of Eli, which Samuel was in the habit of hearing,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and therefore might easily imagine; when thrice called by the Lord, Samuel
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: supposed it to have been Eli.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (24) The voice which Abimelech heard was imaginary, for it is written,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Gen. xx:6, "And God said unto him in a dream." (25) So that the will of God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was manifest to him, not in waking, but only, in sleep, that is, when the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagination is most active and uncontrolled. (26) Some of the Jews believe
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the actual words of the Decalogue were not spoken by God, but that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Israelites heard a noise only, without any distinct words, and during its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: continuance apprehended the Ten Commandments by pure intuition; to this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: opinion I myself once inclined, seeing that the words of the Decalogue in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Exodus are different from the words of the Decalogue in Deuteronomy, for the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: discrepancy seemed to imply (since God only spoke once) that the Ten
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Commandments were not intended to convey the actual words of the Lord, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only His meaning. (27) However, unless we would do violence to Scripture, we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must certainly admit that the Israelites heard a real voice, for Scripture
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: expressly says, Deut. v:4, "God spake with you face to face," i.e. as two
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men ordinarily interchange ideas through the instrumentality of their two
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bodies; and therefore it seems more consonant with Holy Writ to suppose that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God really did create a voice of some kind with which the Decalogue was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revealed. (28) The discrepancy of the two versions is treated of in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Chap. VIII.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (29) Yet not even thus is all difficulty removed, for it seems scarcely
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reasonable to affirm that a created thing, depending on God in the same
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manner as other created things, would be able to express or explain the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of God either verbally or really by means of its individual
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: organism: for instance, by declaring in the first person, "I am the Lord
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: your God."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (30) Certainly when anyone says with his mouth, "I understand," we do not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attribute the understanding to the mouth, but to the mind of the speaker;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: yet this is because the mouth is the natural organ of a man speaking, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the hearer, knowing what understanding is, easily comprehends, by a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: comparison with himself, that the speaker's mind is meant; but if we knew
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing of God beyond the mere name and wished to commune with Him, and be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assured of His existence, I fail to see how our wish would be satisfied by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the declaration of a created thing (depending on God neither more nor less
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than ourselves), "I am the Lord." (31) If God contorted the lips of Moses,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or, I will not say Moses, but some beast, till they pronounced the words,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "I am the Lord," should we apprehend the Lord's existence therefrom?
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (32) Scripture seems clearly to point to the belief that God spoke Himself,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: having descended from heaven to Mount Sinai for the purpose - and not only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the Israelites heard Him speaking, but that their chief men beheld Him
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Ex:xxiv.) (33) Further the law of Moses, which might neither be added to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nor curtailed, and which was set up as a national standard of right, nowhere
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prescribed the belief that God is without body, or even without form or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: figure, but only ordained that the Jews should believe in His existence and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: worship Him alone: it forbade them to invent or fashion any likeness of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Deity, but this was to insure purity of service; because, never having seen
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, they could not by means of images recall the likeness of God, but only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the likeness of some created thing which might thus gradually take the place
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God as the object of their adoration. (34) Nevertheless, the Bible
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: clearly implies that God has a form, and that Moses when he heard God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: speaking was permitted to behold it, or at least its hinder parts.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (35) Doubtless some mystery lurks in this question which we will discuss
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more fully below. (36) For the present I will call attention to the passages
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in Scripture indicating the means by which God has revealed His laws to man.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (37) Revelation may be through figures only, as in I Chron:xxii., where God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: displays his anger to David by means of an angel bearing a sword, and also
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the story of Balaam.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (38) Maimonides and others do indeed maintain that these and every other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instance of angelic apparitions (e.g. to Manoah and to Abraham offering up
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Isaac) occurred during sleep, for that no one with his eyes open ever could
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: see an angel, but this is mere nonsense. (39) The sole object of such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commentators seems to be to extort from Scripture confirmations of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Aristotelian quibbles and their own inventions, a proceeding which I regard
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as the acme of absurdity.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (40) In figures, not real but existing only in the prophet's imagination,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God revealed to Joseph his future lordship, and in words and figures He
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revealed to Joshua that He would fight for the Hebrews, causing to appear an
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: angel, as it were the Captain of the Lord's host, bearing a sword, and by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this means communicating verbally. (41) The forsaking of Israel by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Providence was portrayed to Isaiah by a vision of the Lord, the thrice Holy,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sitting on a very lofty throne, and the Hebrews, stained with the mire of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their sins, sunk as it were in uncleanness, and thus as far as possible
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distant from God. (42) The wretchedness of the people at the time was thus
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revealed, while future calamities were foretold in words. I could cite from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Holy Writ many similar examples, but I think they are sufficiently well
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: known already.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (43) However, we get a still more clear confirmation of our position in Num
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xii:6,7, as follows: "If there be any prophet among you, I the Lord will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: make myself known unto him in a vision" (i.e. by appearances and signs, for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God says of the prophecy of Moses that it was a vision without signs), "and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will speak unto him in a dream" (i.e. not with actual words and an actual
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: voice). (44) "My servant Moses is not so; with him will I speak mouth to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mouth, even apparently, and not in dark speeches, and the similitude of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lord he shall behold," i.e. looking on me as a friend and not afraid, he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: speaks with me (cf. Ex xxxiii:17).
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (45) This makes it indisputable that the other prophets did not hear a real
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: voice, and we gather as much from Deut. xxiv:10: "And there arose not a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophet since in Israel like unto Moses whom the Lord knew face to face,"
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which must mean that the Lord spoke with none other; for not even Moses saw
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Lord's face. (46) These are the only media of communication between
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God and man which I find mentioned in Scripture, and therefore the only ones
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which may be supposed or invented. (47) We may be able quite to comprehend
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that God can communicate immediately with man, for without the intervention
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of bodily means He communicates to our minds His essence; still, a man who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can by pure intuition comprehend ideas which are neither contained in nor
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deducible from the foundations of our natural knowledge, must necessarily
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possess a mind far superior to those of his fellow men, nor do I believe
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that any have been so endowed save Christ. (48) To Him the ordinances of God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: leading men to salvation were revealed directly without words or visions, so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that God manifested Himself to the Apostles through the mind of Christ as He
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: formerly did to Moses through the supernatural voice. (49) In this sense the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: voice of Christ, like the voice which Moses heard, may be called the voice
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God, and it may be said that the wisdom of God (i.e. wisdom more than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human) took upon itself in Christ human nature, and that Christ was the way
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of salvation. (50) I must at this juncture declare that those doctrines
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which certain churches put forward concerning Christ, I neither affirm nor
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deny, for I freely confess that I do not understand them. (51) What I have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: just stated I gather from Scripture, where I never read that God appeared to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Christ, or spoke to Christ, but that God was revealed to the Apostles
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through Christ; that Christ was the Way of Life, and that the old law was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: given through an angel, and not immediately by God; whence it follows that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if Moses spoke with God face to face as a man speaks with his friend (i.e.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by means of their two bodies) Christ communed with God mind to mind.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (52) Thus we may conclude that no one except Christ received the revelations
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God without the aid of imagination, whether in words or vision. (53)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore the power of prophecy implies not a peculiarly perfect mind, but a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: peculiarly vivid imagination, as I will show more clearly in the next
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chapter. (54) We will now inquire what is meant in the Bible by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Spirit of God breathed into the prophets, or by the prophets speaking with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Spirit of God; to that end we must determine the exact signification of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Hebrew word roo'-akh, Strong:7307, commonly translated spirit.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (55) The word roo'-akh, Strong:7307, literally means a wind, e..q. the south
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wind, but it is frequently employed in other derivative significations.

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (65) I have already alluded to the way in which things are referred to God,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and said to be of God.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (66) (1.) As belonging to His nature, and being, as it were, part of Him;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: e.g. the power of God, the eyes of God.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (67) (2.) As under His dominion, and depending on His pleasure; thus the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: heavens are called the heavens of the Lord, as being His chariot
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and habitation. So Nebuchadnezzar is called the servant of God,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Assyria the scourge of God, &c.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (68) (3.) As dedicated to Him, e.g. the Temple of God, a Nazarene of God,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Bread of God.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (69) (4.) As revealed through the prophets and not through our natural
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: faculties. In this sense the Mosaic law is called the law of God.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (70) (5.) As being in the superlative degree. Very high mountains are styled
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mountains of God, a very deep sleep, the sleep of God, &c. In
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this sense we must explain Amos iv:11: "I have overthrown you as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: memorable overthrow, for since God Himself is the Speaker, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passage cannot well be taken otherwise. The wisdom of Solomon is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called the wisdom of God, or extraordinary. The size of the cedars
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Lebanon is alluded to in the Psalmist's expression, "the cedars
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the Lord."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (71) Similarly, if the Jews were at a loss to understand any phenomenon, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were ignorant of its cause, they referred it to God. (72) Thus a storm was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: termed the chiding of God, thunder and lightning the arrows of God, for it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was thought that God kept the winds confined in caves, His treasuries; thus
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: differing merely in name from the Greek wind-god Eolus. (73) In like manner
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miracles were called works of God, as being especially marvellous; though in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reality, of course, all natural events are the works of God, and take place
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solely by His power. (74) The Psalmist calls the miracles in Egypt the works
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God, because the Hebrews found in them a way of safety which they had not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: looked for, and therefore especially marvelled at.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (75) As, then, unusual natural phenomena are called works of God, and trees
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of unusual size are called trees of God, we cannot wonder that very strong
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and tall men, though impious robbers and whoremongers, are in Genesis called
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sons of God.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (76) This reference of things wonderful to God was not peculiar to the Jews.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (77) Pharaoh, on hearing the interpretation of his dream, exclaimed that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind of the gods was in Joseph. (78) Nebuchadnezzar told Daniel that he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possessed the mind of the holy gods; so also in Latin anything well made is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: often said to be wrought with Divine hands, which is equivalent to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Hebrew phrase, wrought with the hand of God.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (80) We can now very easily understand and explain those passages of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scripture which speak of the Spirit of God. (81) In some places the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: expression merely means a very strong, dry, and deadly wind, as in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Isaiah xl:7, "The grass withereth, the flower fadeth, because the Spirit of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Lord bloweth upon it." (82) Similarly in Gen. i:2: "The Spirit of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lord moved over the face of the waters." (83) At other times it is used as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equivalent to a high courage, thus the spirit of Gideon and of Samson is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called the Spirit of the Lord, as being very bold, and prepared for any
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emergency. (84) Any unusual virtue or power is called the Spirit or Virtue
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the Lord, Ex. xxxi:3: "I will fill him (Bezaleel) with the Spirit of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lord," i.e., as the Bible itself explains, with talent above man's usual
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endowment. (85) So Isa. xi:2: "And the Spirit of the Lord shall rest upon
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him," is explained afterwards in the text to mean the spirit of wisdom and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding, of counsel and might.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (86) The melancholy of Saul is called the melancholy of the Lord, or a very
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deep melancholy, the persons who applied the term showing that they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understood by it nothing supernatural, in that they sent for a musician to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assuage it by harp-playing. (87) Again, the "Spirit of the Lord" is used
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as equivalent to the mind of man, for instance, Job xxvii:3: "And the Spirit
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the Lord in my nostrils," the allusion being to Gen. ii:7: "And God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: breathed into man's nostrils the breath of life." (88) Ezekiel also,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophesying to the dead, says (xxvii:14), "And I will give to you My Spirit,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and ye shall live;" i.e. I will restore you to life. (89) In Job xxxiv:14,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we read: "If He gather unto Himself His Spirit and breath;" in Gen. vi:3:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "My Spirit shall not always strive with man, for that he also is flesh,"
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: i.e. since man acts on the dictates of his body, and not the spirit which I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gave him to discern the good, I will let him alone. (90) So, too, Ps. li:12:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "Create in me a clean heart, 0 God, and renew a right spirit within me; cast
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: me not away from Thy presence, and take not Thy Holy Spirit from me." (91)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It was supposed that sin originated only from the body, and that good
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impulses come from the mind; therefore the Psalmist invokes the aid of God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: against the bodily appetites, but prays that the spirit which the Lord, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Holy One, had given him might be renewed. (92) Again, inasmuch as the Bible,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in concession to popular ignorance, describes God as having a mind, a heart,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions - nay, even a body and breath - the expression Spirit of the Lord
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is used for God's mind, disposition, emotion, strength, or breath.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (93) Thus, Isa. xl:13: "Who hath disposed the Spirit of the Lord?" i.e. who,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: save Himself, hath caused the mind of the Lord to will anything,? and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Isa. lxiii:10: "But they rebelled, and vexed the Holy Spirit."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (94) The phrase comes to be used of the law of Moses, which in a sense
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: expounds God's will, Is. lxiii. 11, "Where is He that put His Holy Spirit
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: within him?" meaning, as we clearly gather from the context, the law of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
