text: Moses. (95) Nehemiah, speaking of the giving of the law, says, i:20,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "Thou gavest also thy good Spirit to instruct them." (96) This is referred
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to in Deut. iv:6, "This is your wisdom and understanding," and in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ps. cxliii:10, "Thy good Spirit will lead me into the land of uprightness."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (97) The Spirit of the Lord may mean the breath of the Lord, for breath, no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: less than a mind, a heart, and a body are attributed to God in Scripture, as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in Ps. xxxiii:6. (98) Hence it gets to mean the power, strength, or faculty
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God, as in Job xxxiii:4, "The Spirit of the Lord made me," i.e. the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power, or, if you prefer, the decree of the Lord. (99) So the Psalmist in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: poetic language declares, xxxiii:6, "By the word of the Lord were the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: heavens made, and all the host of them by the breath of His mouth," i.e. by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a mandate issued, as it were, in one breath. (100) Also Ps. cxxxix:7,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "Wither shall I go from Thy Spirit, or whither shall I flee from Thy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: presence?" i.e. whither shall I go so as to be beyond Thy power and Thy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: presence?
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (101) Lastly, the Spirit of the Lord is used in Scripture to express the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions of God, e.g. His kindness and mercy, Micah ii:7, "Is the Spirit
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [i.e. the mercy] of the Lord straitened? (102) Are these cruelties His
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doings?" (103) Zech. iv:6, "Not by might or by power, but My Spirit [i.e.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mercy], saith the Lord of hosts." (104) The twelfth verse of the seventh
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chapter of the same prophet must, I think, be interpreted in like manner:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "Yea, they made their hearts as an adamant stone, lest they should hear the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: law, and the words which the Lord of hosts hath sent in His Spirit [i.e. in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: His mercy] by the former prophets." (105) So also Haggai ii:5: "So My Spirit
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remaineth among you: fear not."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (106) The passage in Isaiah xlviii:16, "And now the Lord and His Spirit hath
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sent me," may be taken to refer to God's mercy or His revealed law; for the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophet says, "From the beginning" (i.e. from the time when I first came to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: you, to preach God's anger and His sentence forth against you) "I spoke not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in secret; from the time that it was, there am I," and now I am sent by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the mercy of God as a joyful messenger to preach your restoration. (107) Or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we may understand him to mean by the revealed law that he had before come to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: warn them by the command of the law (Levit. xix:17) in the same manner under
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same conditions as Moses had warned them, that now, like Moses, he ends
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by preaching their restoration. (108) But the first explanation seems to me
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the best.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (109) Returning, then, to the main object of our discussion, we find that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Scriptural phrases, "The Spirit of the Lord was upon a prophet," "The
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lord breathed His Spirit into men," "Men were filled with the Spirit of God,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the Holy Spirit," &c., are quite clear to us, and mean that prophets
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were endowed with a peculiar and extraordinary power, and devoted themselves
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to piety with especial constancy(3); that thus they perceived the mind or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the thought of God, for we have shown that God's Spirit signifies in Hebrew
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God's mind or thought, and that the law which shows His mind and thought is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called His Spirit; hence that the imagination of the prophets, inasmuch as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through it were revealed the decrees of God, may equally be called the mind
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God, and the prophets be said to have possessed the mind of God. (110) On
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our minds also the mind of God and His eternal thoughts are impressed; but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this being the same for all men is less taken into account, especially by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Hebrews, who claimed a pre-eminence, and despised other men and other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men's knowledge.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (111) Lastly, the prophets were said to possess the Spirit of God because
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men knew not the cause of prophetic knowledge, and in their wonder referred
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it with other marvels directly to the Deity, styling it Divine knowledge.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (112) We need no longer scruple to affirm that the prophets only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perceived God's revelation by the aid of imagination, that is, by words and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: figures either real or imaginary. (113) We find no other means mentioned in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scripture, and therefore must not invent any. (114) As to the particular law
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Nature by which the communications took place, I confess my ignorance.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (115) I might, indeed, say as others do, that they took place by the power
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God; but this would be mere trifling, and no better than explaining some
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unique specimen by a transcendental term. (116) Everything takes place by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the power of God. (117) Nature herself is the power of God under another
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: name, and our ignorance of the power of God is co-extensive with our
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ignorance of Nature. (118) It is absolute folly, therefore, to ascribe an
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: event to the power of God when we know not its natural cause, which is the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of God.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (119) However, we are not now inquiring into the causes of prophetic
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge. (120) We are only attempting, as I have said, to examine the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scriptural documents, and to draw our conclusions from them as from ultimate
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural facts; the causes of the documents do not concern us.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (121) As the prophets perceived the revelations of God by the aid of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagination, they could indisputably perceive much that is beyond the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: boundary of the intellect, for many more ideas can be constructed from words
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and figures than from the principles and notions on which the whole fabric
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of reasoned knowledge is reared.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (122) Thus we have a clue to the fact that the prophets perceived nearly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everything in parables and allegories, and clothed spiritual truths in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bodily forms, for such is the usual method of imagination. (122) We need no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: longer wonder that Scripture and the prophets speak so strangely and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obscurely of God's Spirit or Mind (cf. Numbers xi:17, 1 Kings xxii:21, &c.),
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the Lord was seen by Micah as sitting, by Daniel as an old man clothed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in white, by Ezekiel as a fire, that the Holy Spirit appeared to those with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Christ as a descending dove, to the apostles as fiery tongues, to Paul on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his conversion as a great light. (124) All these expressions are plainly in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: harmony with the current ideas of God and spirits.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (125) Inasmuch as imagination is fleeting and inconstant, we find that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of prophecy did not remain with a prophet for long, nor manifest
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself frequently, but was very rare; manifesting itself only in a few men,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and in them not often.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (126) We must necessarily inquire how the prophets became assured of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: truth of what they perceived by imagination, and not by sure mental laws;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but our investigation must be confined to Scripture, for the subject is one
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on which we cannot acquire certain knowledge, and which we cannot explain by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the immediate causes. (127) Scripture teaching about the assurance of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophets I will treat of in the next chapter.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: CHAPTER II. - OF PROPHETS.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (1) It follows from the last chapter that, as I have said, the prophets were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endowed with unusually vivid imaginations, and not with unusually, perfect
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: minds. (2) This conclusion is amply sustained by Scripture, for we are told
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that Solomon was the wisest of men, but had no special faculty of prophecy.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (3) Heman, Calcol, and Dara, though men of great talent, were not prophets,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereas uneducated countrymen, nay, even women, such as Hagar, Abraham's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: handmaid, were thus gifted. (4) Nor is this contrary to ordinary experience
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and reason. (5) Men of great imaginative power are less fitted for abstract
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reasoning, whereas those who excel in intellect and its use keep their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imagination more restrained and controlled, holding it in subjection, so to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: speak, lest it should usurp the place of reason.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (6) Thus to suppose that knowledge of natural and spiritual phenomena can be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gained from the prophetic books, is an utter mistake, which I shall
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour to expose, as I think philosophy, the age, and the question itself
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: demand. (7) I care not for the girdings of superstition, for superstition is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the bitter enemy, of all true knowledge and true morality. (8) Yes; it has
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: come to this! (9) Men who openly confess that they can form no idea of God,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and only know Him through created things, of which they know not the causes,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can unblushingly, accuse philosophers of Atheism. (10) Treating the question
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: methodically, I will show that prophecies varied, not only according to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the imagination and physical temperament of the prophet, but also according
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to his particular opinions; and further that prophecy never rendered the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophet wiser than he was before. (11) But I will first discuss the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assurance of truth which the prophets received, for this is akin to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subject-matter of the chapter, and will serve to elucidate somewhat our
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present point.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (12) Imagination does not, in its own nature, involve any certainty of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: truth, such as is implied in every clear and distinct idea, but requires
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: some extrinsic reason to assure us of its objective reality: hence prophecy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot afford certainty, and the prophets were assured of God's revelation
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by some sign, and not by the fact of revelation, as we may see from Abraham,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who, when he had heard the promise of God, demanded a sign, not because he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: did not believe in God, but because he wished to be sure that it was God Who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: made the promise. (13) The fact is still more evident in the case of Gideon:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "Show me," he says to God, "show me a sign, that I may know that it is Thou
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that talkest with me." (14) God also says to Moses: "And let this be a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sign that I have sent thee." (15) Hezekiah, though he had long known Isaiah
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be a prophet, none the less demanded a sign of the cure which he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: predicted. (15) It is thus quite evident that the prophets always received
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: some sign to certify them of their prophetic imaginings; and for this reason
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses bids the Jews (Deut. xviii.) ask of the prophets a sign, namely, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prediction of some coming event. (16) In this respect, prophetic knowledge
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is inferior to natural knowledge, which needs no sign, and in itself implies
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certitude. (17) Moreover, Scripture warrants the statement that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certitude of the prophets was not mathematical, but moral. (18) Moses lays
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: down the punishment of death for the prophet who preaches new gods, even
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: though he confirm his doctrine by signs and wonders (Deut. xiii.); "For," he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: says, "the Lord also worketh signs and wonders to try His people." (19) And
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jesus Christ warns His disciples of the same thing (Matt. xxiv:24). (20)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Furthermore, Ezekiel (xiv:9) plainly states that God sometimes deceives
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men with false revelations; and Micaiah bears like witness in the case of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the prophets of Ahab.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (21) Although these instances go to prove that revelation is open to doubt,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it nevertheless contains, as we have said, a considerable element of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certainty, for God never deceives the good, nor His chosen, but (according
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the ancient proverb, and as appears in the history of Abigail and her
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: speech), God uses the good as instruments of goodness, and the wicked as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: means to execute His wrath. (22) This may be seen from the case of Micaiah
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: above quoted; for although God had determined to deceive Ahab, through
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophets, He made use of lying prophets; to the good prophet He revealed the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: truth, and did not forbid his proclaiming it.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (23) Still the certitude of prophecy, remains, as I have said, merely,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: moral; for no one can justify himself before God, nor boast that he is an
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instrument for God's goodness. (24) Scripture itself teaches and shows that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God led away David to number the people, though it bears ample
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: witness to David's piety.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (25) The whole question of the certitude of prophecy, was based on these
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: three considerations:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 1. That the things revealed were imagined very vividly, affecting the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophets in the same way as things seen when awake;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 2. The presence of a sign;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 3. Lastly, and chiefly, that the mind of the prophet was given wholly,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to what was right and  good.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (26) Although Scripture does not always make mention of a sign, we must
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nevertheless suppose that a sign was always vouchsafed; for Scripture does
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not always relate every condition and circumstance (as many, have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remarked), but rather takes them for granted. (27) We may, however, admit
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that no sign was needed when the prophecy declared nothing that was not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: already contained in the law of Moses, because it was confirmed by that law.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (28) For instance, Jeremiah's prophecy, of the destruction of Jerusalem was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confirmed by the prophecies of other prophets, and by the threats in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: law, and, therefore, it needed no sign; whereas Hananiah, who, contrary to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all the prophets, foretold the speedy restoration of the state, stood in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: need of a sign, or he would have been in doubt as to the truth of his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophecy, until it was confirmed by facts. (29) "The prophet which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophesieth of peace, when the word of the prophet shall come to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pass, then shall the prophet be known that the Lord hath truly sent him."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (30) As, then, the certitude afforded to the prophet by signs was not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mathematical (i.e. did not necessarily follow from the perception of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing perceived or seen), but only moral, and as the signs were only given
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to convince the prophet, it follows that such signs were given according to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the opinions and capacity of each prophet, so that a sign which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: convince one prophet would fall far short of convincing another who was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imbued with different opinions. (31) Therefore the signs varied according to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the individual prophet.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (32) So also did the revelation vary, as we have stated, according to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual disposition and temperament, and according to the opinions
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: previously held.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (33) It varied according to disposition, in this way: if a prophet was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cheerful, victories, peace, and events which make men glad, were revealed to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him; in that he was naturally more likely to imagine such things. (34) If,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on the contrary, he was melancholy, wars, massacres, and calamities were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revealed; and so, according as a prophet was merciful, gentle, quick to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anger, or severe, he was more fitted for one kind of revelation than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another. (35) It varied according to the temper of imagination in this way:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if a prophet was cultivated he perceived the mind of God in a cultivated
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: way, if he was confused he perceived it confusedly. (36) And so with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revelations perceived through visions. (37) If a prophet was a countryman he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: saw visions of oxen, cows, and the like; if he was a soldier, he saw
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: generals and armies; if a courtier, a royal throne, and so on.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (38) Lastly, prophecy varied according to the opinions held by the prophets;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for instance, to the Magi, who believed in the follies of astrology, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: birth of Christ was revealed through the vision of a star in the East. (39)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: To the augurs of Nebuchadnezzar the destruction of Jerusalem was revealed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through entrails, whereas the king himself inferred it from oracles and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: direction of arrows which he shot into the air. (40) To prophets who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believed that man acts from free choice and by his own power, God was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revealed as standing apart from and ignorant of future human actions. (41)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: All of which we will illustrate from Scripture.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (42) The first point is proved from the case of Elisha, who, in order to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophecy to Jehoram, asked for a harp, and was unable to perceive the Divine
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: purpose till he had been recreated by its music; then, indeed, he prophesied
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to Jehoram and to his allies glad tidings, which previously he had been
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unable to attain to because he was angry with the king, and these who are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: angry with anyone can imagine evil of him, but not good. (43) The theory
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that God does not reveal Himself to the angry or the sad, is a mere dream:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for God revealed to Moses while angry, the terrible slaughter of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: firstborn, and did so without the intervention of a harp. (44) To Cain in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his rage, God was revealed, and to Ezekiel, impatient with anger, was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revealed the contumacy and wretchedness of the Jews. (45) Jeremiah,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miserable and weary of life, prophesied the disasters of the Hebrews, so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that Josiah would not consult him, but inquired of a woman, inasmuch as it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was more in accordance with womanly nature that God should reveal His mercy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereto. (46) So, Micaiah never prophesied good to Ahab, though other true
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophets had done so, but invariably evil. (46) Thus we see that individual
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophets were by temperament more fitted for one sort of revelation than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (47) The style of the prophecy also varied according to the eloquence of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individual prophet. (48) The prophecies of Ezekiel and Amos are not written
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in a cultivated style like those of Isaiah and Nahum, but more rudely. (49)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Any Hebrew scholar who wishes to inquire into this point more closely, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compares chapters of the different prophets treating of the same subject,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will find great dissimilarity of style. (50) Compare, for instance, chap. i.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the courtly Isaiah, verse 11 to verse 20, with chap. v. of the countryman
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Amos, verses 21-24. (51) Compare also the order and reasoning of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophecies of Jeremiah, written in Idumaea (chap. xlix.), with the order and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reasoning of Obadiah. (52) Compare, lastly, Isa. xl:19, 20, and xliv:8, with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Hosea viii:6, and xiii:2. And so on.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (53) A due consideration of these passage will clearly show us that God has
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no particular style in speaking, but, according to the learning and capacity
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the prophet, is cultivated, compressed, severe, untutored, prolix, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obscure.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (54) There was, moreover, a certain variation in the visions vouchsafed to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the prophets, and in the symbols by which they expressed them, for Isaiah
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: saw the glory of the Lord departing from the Temple in a different form from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that presented to Ezekiel. (55) The Rabbis, indeed, maintain that both
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: visions were really the same, but that Ezekiel, being a countryman, was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: above measure impressed by it, and therefore set it forth in full detail;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but unless there is a trustworthy tradition on the subject, which I do not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for a moment believe, this theory is plainly an invention. Isaiah saw
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seraphim with six wings, Ezekiel beasts with four wings; Isaiah saw God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: clothed and sitting on a royal throne, Ezekiel saw Him in the likeness of a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fire; each doubtless saw God under the form in which he usually imagined
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Him.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (56) Further, the visions varied in clearness as well as in details; for the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revelations of Zechariah were too obscure to be understood by the prophet
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without explanation, as appears from his narration of them; the visions of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Daniel could not be understood by him even after they had been explained,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and this obscurity did not arise from the difficulty of the matter revealed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (for being merely human affairs, these only transcended human capacity in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being future), but solely in the fact that Daniel's imagination was not so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: capable for prophecy while he was awake as while he was asleep; and this is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further evident from the fact that at the very beginning of the vision he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was so terrified that he almost despaired of his strength. (57) Thus, on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: account of the inadequacy of his imagination and his strength, the things
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revealed were so obscure to him that he could not understand them even after
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they had been explained. (58) Here we may note that the words heard by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Daniel, were, as we have shown above, simply imaginary, so that it is hardly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wonderful that in his frightened state he imagined them so confusedly and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obscurely that afterwards he could make nothing of them. (59) Those who say
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that God did not wish to make a clear revelation, do not seem to have read
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the words of the angel, who expressly says that he came to make the prophet
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand what should befall his people in the latter days (Dan. x:14).
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (60) The revelation remained obscure because no one was found, at that time,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with imagination sufficiently strong to conceive it more clearly. (61)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lastly, the prophets, to whom it was revealed that God would take away
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Elijah, wished to persuade Elisha that he had been taken somewhere where
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they would find him; showing sufficiently clearly that they had not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understood God's revelation aright.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (62) There is no need to set this out more amply, for nothing is more plain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the Bible than that God endowed some prophets with far greater gifts of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophecy than others. (63) But I will show in greater detail and length, for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I consider the point more important, that the prophecies varied according to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the opinions previously embraced by the prophets, and that the prophets held
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: diverse and even contrary opinions and prejudices. (64) (I speak, be it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understood, solely of matters speculative, for in regard to uprightness and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: morality the case is widely different.) (65) From thence I shall conclude
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that prophecy never rendered the prophets more learned, but left them with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their former opinions, and that we are, therefore, not at all bound to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: trust them in matters of intellect.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (66) Everyone has been strangely hasty in affirming that the prophets knew
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everything within the scope of human intellect; and, although certain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passages of Scripture plainly affirm that the prophets were in certain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: respects ignorant, such persons would rather say that they do not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand the passages than admit that there was anything which the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophets did not know; or else they try to wrest the Scriptural words away
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from their evident meaning.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (67) If either of these proceedings is allowable we may as well shut our
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Bibles, for vainly shall we attempt to prove anything from them if their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: plainest passages may be classed among obscure and impenetrable mysteries,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or if we may put any interpretation on them which we fancy. (68) For
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instance, nothing is more clear in the Bible than that Joshua, and perhaps
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also the author who wrote his history, thought that the sun revolves round
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the earth, and that the earth is fixed, and further that the sun for a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain period remained still. (69) Many, who will not admit any movement in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the heavenly bodies, explain away the passage till it seems to mean
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something quite different; others, who have learned to philosophize more
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: correctly, and understand that the earth moves while the sun is still, or at
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any rate does not revolve round the earth, try with all their might to wrest
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this meaning from Scripture, though plainly nothing of the sort is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intended. (70) Such quibblers excite my wonder! (71) Are we, forsooth, bound
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to believe that Joshua the Soldier was a learned astronomer? or that a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miracle could not be revealed to him, or that the light of the sun could not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remain longer than usual above the horizon, without his knowing the cause?
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (72) To me both alternatives appear ridiculous, and therefore I would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rather say, that Joshua was ignorant of the true cause of the lengthened
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: day, and that he and the whole host with him thought that the sun moved
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: round the earth every day, and that on that particular occasion it stood
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: still for a time, thus causing the light to remain longer; and I would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: say, that they did not conjecture that, from the amount of snow in the air
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (see Josh. x:11), the refraction may have been greater than usual, or that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: there may have been some other cause which we will not now inquire into.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (73) So also the sign of the shadow going back was revealed to Isaiah
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to his understanding; that is, as proceeding from a going
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: backwards of the sun; for he, too, thought that the sun moves and that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: earth is still; of parhelia he perhaps never even dreamed. (74) We may
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arrive at this conclusion without any, scruple, for the sign could really
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have come to pass, and have been predicted by Isaiah to the king, without
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the prophet being aware of the real cause.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (75) With regard to the building of the Temple by Solomon, if it was really
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dictate by God we must maintain the same doctrine: namely, that all the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: measurements were revealed according to the opinions and understanding of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the king; for as we are not bound to believe that Solomon was a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mathematician, we may affirm that he was ignorant of the true ratio between
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the circumference and the diameter of a circle, and that, like the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: generality of workmen, he thought that it was as three to one. (76) But if
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is allowable to declare that we do not understand the passage, in good
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sooth I know nothing in the Bible that we can understand; for the process of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: building is there narrated simply and as a mere matter of history. (77) If,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: again, it is permitted to pretend that the passage has another meaning, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was written as it is from some reason unknown to us, this is no less than a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: complete subversal of the Bible; for every absurd and evil invention of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human perversity could thus, without detriment to Scriptural authority, be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: defended and fostered. (78) Our conclusion is in no wise impious, for though
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Solomon, Isaiah, Joshua, &c. were prophets, they were none the less men, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as such not exempt from human shortcomings.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (79) According to the understanding of Noah it was revealed to him that God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as about to destroy the whole human race, for Noah thought that beyond the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: limits of Palestine the world was not inhabited.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (80) Not only in matters of this kind, but in others more important, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: about the Divine attributes, but held quite ordinary notions about God, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to these notions their revelations were adapted, as I will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: demonstrate by ample Scriptural testimony; from all which one may easily see
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that they were praised and commended, not so much for the sublimity and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eminence of their intellect as for their piety and faithfulness.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (81) Adam, the first man to whom God was revealed, did not know that He is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: omnipotent and omniscient; for he hid himself from Him, and attempted to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: make excuses for his fault before God, as though he had had to do with a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man; therefore to him also was God revealed according to his understanding -
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is, as being unaware of his situation or his sin, for Adam
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: heard, or seemed to hear, the Lord walling, in the garden, calling him and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: asking him where he was; and then, on seeing his shamefacedness, asking him
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whether he had eaten of the forbidden fruit. (82) Adam evidently only knew
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Deity as the Creator of all things. (83) To Cain also God was revealed,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to his understanding, as ignorant of human affairs, nor was a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: higher conception of the Deity required for repentance of his sin.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (83) To Laban the Lord revealed Himself as the God of Abraham, because Laban
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believed that each nation had its own special divinity (see Gen. xxxi:29).
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (84) Abraham also knew not that God is omnipresent, and has foreknowledge of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all things; for when he heard the sentence against the inhabitants of Sodom,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he prayed that the Lord should not execute it till He had ascertained
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whether they all merited such punishment; for he said (see Gen. xviii:24),
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "Peradventure there be fifty righteous within the city," and in accordance
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with this belief God was revealed to him; as Abraham imagined, He spake
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thus: "I will go down now, and see whether they have done altogether
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to the cry of it which is come unto Me; and, if not, I will know."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (85) Further, the Divine testimony concerning Abraham asserts nothing but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that he was obedient, and that he "commanded his household after him that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they should keep the way of the Lord" (Gen. xviii:19); it does not state
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that he held sublime conceptions of the Deity.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (86) Moses, also, was not sufficiently aware that God is omniscient, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: directs human actions by His sole decree, for although God Himself says that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Israelites should hearken to Him, Moses still considered the matter
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doubtful and repeated, "But if they will not believe me, nor hearken unto my
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: voice." (87) To him in like manner God was revealed as taking no part in,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and as being ignorant of, future human actions: the Lord gave him two signs
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and said, "And it shall come to pass that if they will not believe thee,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: neither hearken to the voice of the first sign, that they will believe the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: voice of the latter sign; but if not, thou shalt take of the water of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: river," &c. (88) Indeed, if any one considers without prejudice the recorded
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: opinions of Moses, he will plainly see that Moses conceived the Deity as a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Being Who has always existed, does exist, and always will exist, and for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this cause he calls Him by the name Jehovah, which in Hebrew signifies these
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: three phases of existence: as to His nature, Moses only taught that He is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: merciful, gracious, and exceeding jealous, as appears from many passages in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Pentateuch. (89) Lastly, he believed and taught that this Being was so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different from all other beings, that He could not be expressed by the image
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of any visible thing; also, that He could not be looked upon, and that not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so much from inherent impossibility as from human infirmity; further, that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by reason of His power He was without equal and unique. (90) Moses admitted,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indeed, that there were beings (doubtless by the plan and command of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lord) who acted as God's vicegerents - that is, beings to whom God had given
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the right, authority, and power to direct nations, and to provide and care
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for them; but he taught that this Being Whom they were bound to obey was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the highest and Supreme God, or (to use the Hebrew phrase) God of gods, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thus in the song (Exod. xv:11) he exclaims, "Who is like unto Thee, 0 Lord,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: among the gods?" and Jethro says (Exod. xviii:11), "Now I know that the Lord
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is greater than all gods." (91) That is to say, "I am at length compelled to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: admit to Moses that Jehovah is greater than all gods, and that His power
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is unrivalled." (92) We must remain in doubt whether Moses thought that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: these beings who acted as God's vicegerents were created by Him, for he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has stated nothing, so far as we know, about their creation and origin. (93)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: He further taught that this Being had brought the visible world into order
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from Chaos, and had given Nature her germs, and therefore that He
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possesses supreme right and power over all things; further, that by reason
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of this supreme right and power He had chosen for Himself alone the Hebrew
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nation and a certain strip of territory, and had handed over to the care of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other gods substituted by Himself the rest of the nations and territories,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and that therefore He was called the God of Israel and the God of Jerusalem,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereas the other gods were called the gods of the Gentiles. (94) For this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason the Jews believed that the strip of territory which God had chosen
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for Himself, demanded a Divine worship quite apart and different from the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: worship which obtained elsewhere, and that the Lord would not suffer the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: worship of other gods adapted to other countries. (95) Thus they thought
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the people whom the king of Assyria had brought into Judaea were torn
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in pieces by lions because they knew not the worship of the National
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divinity (2 Kings xvii:25).
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (96) Jacob, according to Aben Ezra's opinion, therefore admonished his sons
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when he wished them to seek out a new country, that they should prepare
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves for a new worship, and lay aside the worship of strange, gods -
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is, of the gods of the land where they were (Gen. xxxv:2, 3).
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (97) David, in telling Saul that he was compelled by the king's persecution
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to live away from his country, said that he was driven out from the heritage
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the Lord, and sent to worship other gods (1 Sam. xxvi:19). (98) Lastly,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he believed that this Being or Deity had His habitation in the heavens
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Deut. xxxiii:27), an opinion very common among the Gentiles.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (99) If we now examine the revelations to Moses, we shall find that they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were accommodated to these opinions; as he believed that the Divine Nature
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was subject to the conditions of mercy, graciousness, &c., so God was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revealed to him in accordance with his idea and under these attributes (see
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Exodus xxxiv:6, 7, and the second commandment). (100) Further it is related
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Ex. xxxiii:18) that Moses asked of God that he might behold Him, but as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses (as we have said) had formed no mental image of God, and God (as I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have shown) only revealed Himself to the prophets in accordance with the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: disposition of their imagination, He did not reveal Himself in any form.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (101) This, I repeat, was because the imagination of Moses was unsuitable,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for other prophets bear witness that they saw the Lord; for instance,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Isaiah, Ezekiel, Daniel, &c. (102) For this reason God answered Moses, "Thou
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: canst not see My face;" and inasmuch as Moses believed that God can be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: looked upon - that is, that no contradiction of the Divine nature is therein
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involved (for otherwise he would never have preferred his request) - it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: added, "For no one shall look on Me and live," thus giving a reason in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accordance with Moses' idea, for it is not stated that a contradiction of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Divine nature would be involved, as was really the case, but that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing would not come to pass because of human infirmity.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (103) When God would reveal to Moses that the Israelites, because they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: worshipped the calf, were to be placed in the same category as other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nations, He said (ch. xxxiii:2, 3), that He would send an angel (that is, a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being who should have charge of the Israelites, instead of the Supreme
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Being), and that He Himself would no longer remain among them; thus leaving
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses no ground for supposing that the Israelites were more beloved by God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than the other nations whose guardianship He had entrusted to other beings
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or angels (vide verse 16).
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (104) Lastly, as Moses believed that God dwelt in the heavens, God was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revealed to him as coming down from heaven on to a mountain, and in order to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: talk with the Lord Moses went up the mountain, which he certainly need not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have done if he could have conceived of God as omnipresent.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (105) The Israelites knew scarcely anything of God, although He was revealed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to them; and this is abundantly evident from their transferring, a few days
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: afterwards, the honour and worship due to Him to a calf, which they believed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be the god who had brought them out of Egypt. (106) In truth, it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hardly likely that men accustomed to the superstitions of Egypt,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: uncultivated and sunk in most abject slavery, should have held any sound
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: notions about the Deity, or that Moses should have taught them anything
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: beyond a rule of right living; inculcating it not like a philosopher, as the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: result of freedom, but like a lawgiver compelling them to be moral by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: legal authority. (107) Thus the rule of right living, the worship and love
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God, was to them rather a bondage than the true liberty, the gift and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: grace of the Deity. (108) Moses bid them love God and keep His law, because
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they had in the past received benefits from Him (such as the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deliverance from slavery in Egypt), and further terrified them with threats
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if they transgressed His commands, holding out many promises of good if they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should observe them; thus treating them as parents treat irrational
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: children. It is, therefore, certain that they knew not the excellence of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue and the true happiness.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (109) Jonah thought that he was fleeing from the sight of God, which seems
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to show that he too held that God had entrusted the care of the nations
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: outside Judaea to other substituted powers. (110) No one in the whole of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Old Testament speaks more rationally of God than Solomon, who in fact
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: surpassed all the men of his time in natural ability. (111) Yet he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: considered himself above the law (esteeming it only to have been given for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men without reasonable and intellectual grounds for their actions), and made
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: small account of the laws concerning kings, which are mainly three: nay, he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: openly violated them (in this he did wrong, and acted in a manner unworthy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of a philosopher, by indulging in sensual pleasure), and taught that all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Fortune's favours to mankind are vanity, that humanity has no nobler gift
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than wisdom, and no greater punishment than folly.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (112) See Proverbs xvi:22, 23.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (113) But let us return to the prophets whose conflicting opinions we have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: undertaken to note. (114) The expressed ideas of Ezekiel seemed so diverse
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from those of Moses to the Rabbis who have left us the extant prophetic
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: books (as is told in the treatise of Sabbathus, i:13, 2), that they had
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: serious thoughts of omitting his prophecy from the canon, and would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doubtless have thus excluded it if a certain Hananiah had not undertaken to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explain it; a task which (as is there narrated) he with great zeal and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: labour accomplished. (115) How he did so does not sufficiently appear,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whether it was by writing a commentary which has now perished, or by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: altering Ezekiel's words and audaciously - striking out phrases according to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his fancy. (116) However this may be, chapter xviii. certainly does not seem
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to agree with Exodus xxxiv:7, Jeremiah xxxii:18, &c.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (117 ) Samuel believed that the Lord never repented of anything He had
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
