text: decreed (1 Sam. xv:29), for when Saul was sorry for his sin, and wished to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: worship God and ask for forgiveness, Samuel said that the Lord would not go
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: back from his decree.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (118) To Jeremiah, on the other hand, it was revealed that, "If that nation
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: against whom I (the Lord) have pronounced, turn from their evil, I will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repent of the evil that I thought to do unto them. (119) If it do evil in my
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sight, that it obey not my voice, then I will repent of the good wherewith I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said I would benefit them" (Jer. xviii:8-10). (120) Joel (ii:13) taught that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Lord repented Him only of evil. (121) Lastly, it is clear from Gen iv: 7
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that a man can overcome the temptations of sin, and act righteously; for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this doctrine is told to Cain, though, as we learn from Josephus and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scriptures, he never did so overcome them. (122) And this agrees with the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chapter of Jeremiah just cited, for it is there said that the Lord repents
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the good or the evil pronounced, if the men in question change their ways
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and manner of life. (123) But, on the other hand, Paul (Rom.ix:10) teaches
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as plainly as possible that men have no control over the temptations of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: flesh save by the special vocation and grace of God. (124) And when
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Rom. iii:5 and vi:19) he attributes righteousness to man, he corrects
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself as speaking merely humanly and through the infirmity of the flesh.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (125) We have now more than sufficiently proved our point, that God adapted
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revelations to the understanding and opinions of the prophets, and that in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: matters of theory without bearing on charity or morality the prophets could
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be, and, in fact, were, ignorant, and held conflicting opinions. (126) It
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore follows that we must by no means go to the prophets for knowledge,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: either of natural or of spiritual phenomena.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (127) We have determined, then, that we are only bound to believe in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophetic writings, the object and substance of the revelation; with regard
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the details, every one may believe or not, as he likes.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (128) For instance, the revelation to Cain only teaches us that God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: admonished him to lead the true life, for such alone is the object and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: substance of the revelation, not doctrines concerning free will and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: philosophy. (129) Hence, though the freedom of the will is clearly implied
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the words of the admonition, we are at liberty to hold a contrary
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: opinion, since the words and reasons were adapted to the understanding of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Cain.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (130) So, too, the revelation to Micaiah would only teach that God revealed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to him the true issue of the battle between Ahab and Aram; and this is all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we are bound to believe. (131) Whatever else is contained in the revelation
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning the true and the false Spirit of God, the army of heaven standing
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on the right hand and on the left, and all the other details, does not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affect us at all. (132) Everyone may believe as much of it as his reason
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: allows.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (132) The reasonings by which the Lord displayed His power to Job (if they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: really were a revelation, and the author of the history is narrating, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not merely, as some suppose, rhetorically adorning his own conceptions),
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would come under the same category - that is, they were adapted to Job's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding, for the purpose of convincing him, and are not universal,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or for the convincing of all men.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (133) We can come to no different conclusion with respect to the reasonings
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Christ, by which He convicted the Pharisees of pride and ignorance, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exhorted His disciples to lead the true life. (134) He adapted them to each
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man's opinions and principles. (135) For instance, when He said to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Pharisees (Matt. xii:26), "And if Satan cast out devils, his house is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: divided against itself, how then shall his kingdom stand? (136) "He only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wished to convince the Pharisees according, to their own principles, not to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: teach that there are devils, or any kingdom of devils. (137) So, too,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when He said to His disciples (Matt. viii:10), "See that ye despise not one
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of these little ones, for I say unto you that their angels," &c., He merely
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desired to warn them against pride and despising any of their fellows, not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to insist on the actual reason given, which was simply adopted in order to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persuade them more easily.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (138) Lastly, we should say, exactly the same of the apostolic signs and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reasonings, but there is no need to go further into the subject. (139) If I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were to enumerate all the passages of Scripture addressed only to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individuals, or to a particular man's understanding, and which cannot,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without great danger to philosophy, be defended as Divine doctrines, I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should go far beyond the brevity at which I aim. (140) Let it suffice, then,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to have indicated a few instances of general application, and let the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: curious reader consider others by himself. (141) Although the points we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have just raised concerning prophets and prophecy are the only ones which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have any direct bearing on the end in view, namely, the separation of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Philosophy from Theology, still, as I have touched on the general question,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I may here inquire whether the gift of prophecy was peculiar to the Hebrews,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or whether it was common to all nations. (142) I must then come to a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conclusion about the vocation of the Hebrews, all of which I shall do in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ensuing chapter.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: CHAPTER III.  OF THE VOCATION OF THE HEBREWS, AND
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: WHETHER THE GIFT OF PROPHECY WAS PECULIAR TO THEM.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (1) Every man's true happiness and blessedness consist solely in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: enjoyment of what is good, not in the pride that he alone is enjoying it, to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the exclusion of others. (2) He who thinks himself the more blessed because
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he is enjoying benefits which others are not, or because he is more blessed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or more fortunate than his fellows, is ignorant of true happiness and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blessedness, and the joy which he feels is either childish or envious and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: malicious. (3) For instance, a man's true happiness consists only in wisdom,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the knowledge of the truth, not at all in the fact that he is wiser than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: others, or that others lack such knowledge: such considerations do not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: increase his wisdom or true happiness.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (4) Whoever, therefore, rejoices for such reasons, rejoices in another's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: misfortune, and is, so far, malicious and bad, knowing neither true
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: happiness nor the peace of the true life.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (5) When Scripture, therefore, in exhorting the Hebrews to obey the law,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: says that the Lord has chosen them for Himself before other nations
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Deut. x:15); that He is near them, but not near others (Deut. iv:7); that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to them alone He has given just laws (Deut. iv:8); and, lastly, that He has
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: marked them out before others (Deut. iv:32); it speaks only according to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding of its hearers, who, as we have shown in the last chapter, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as Moses also testifies (Deut. ix:6, 7), knew not true blessedness. (6) For
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in good sooth they would have been no less blessed if God had called all men
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equally to salvation, nor would God have been less present to them for being
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equally present to others; their laws, would have been no less just if they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had been ordained for all, and they themselves would have been no less wise.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (7) The miracles would have shown God's power no less by being wrought for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other nations also; lastly, the Hebrews would have been just as much bound
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to worship God if He had bestowed all these gifts equally on all men.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (8) When God tells Solomon (1 Kings iii:12) that no one shall be as wise as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he in time to come, it seems to be only a manner of expressing surpassing
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wisdom; it is little to be believed that God would have promised Solomon,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for his greater happiness, that He would never endow anyone with so much
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wisdom in time to come; this would in no wise have increased Solomon's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intellect, and the wise king would have given equal thanks to the Lord if
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everyone had been gifted with the same faculties.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (9) Still, though we assert that Moses, in the passages of the Pentateuch
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: just cited, spoke only according to the understanding of the Hebrews, we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have no wish to deny that God ordained the Mosaic law for them alone, nor
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that He spoke to them alone, nor that they witnessed marvels beyond those
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which happened to any other nation; but we wish to emphasize that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses desired to admonish the Hebrews in such a manner, and with such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reasonings as would appeal most forcibly to their childish understanding,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and constrain them to worship the Deity. (10) Further, we wished to show
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the Hebrews did not surpass other nations in knowledge, or in piety,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but evidently in some attribute different from these; or (to speak like the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scriptures, according to their understanding), that the Hebrews were not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chosen by God before others for the sake of the true life and sublime ideas,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: though they were often thereto admonished, but with some other object. (11)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: What that object was, I will duly show.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (12) But before I begin, I wish in a few words to explain what I mean by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: guidance of God, by the help of God, external and inward, and, lastly, what
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I understand by fortune.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (13) By the help of God, I mean the fixed and unchangeable order of nature
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or the chain of natural events: for I have said before and shown elsewhere
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the universal laws of nature, according to which all things exist and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are determined, are only another name for the eternal decrees of God, which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: always involve eternal truth and necessity.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (14) So that to say that everything happens according to natural laws, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to say that everything is ordained by the decree and ordinance of God, is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same thing. (15) Now since the power in nature is identical with the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of God, by which alone all things happen and are determined, it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows that whatsoever man, as a part of nature, provides himself with to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: aid and preserve his existence, or whatsoever nature affords him without his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: help, is given to him solely by the Divine power, acting either through
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human nature or through external circumstance. (16) So whatever human nature
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can furnish itself with by its own efforts to preserve its existence, may
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be fitly called the inward aid of God, whereas whatever else accrues to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man's profit from outward causes may be called the external aid of God.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17) We can now easily understand what is meant by the election of God. (18)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For since no one can do anything save by the predetermined order of nature,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is by God's eternal ordinance and decree, it follows that no one can
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: choose a plan of life for himself, or accomplish any work save by God's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vocation choosing him for the work or the plan of life in question, rather
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than any other. (19) Lastly, by fortune, I mean the ordinance of God in so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far as it directs human life through external and unexpected means. (20)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: With these preliminaries I return to my purpose of discovering the reason
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: why the Hebrews were said to be elected by God before other nations, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the demonstration I thus proceed.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (21) All objects of legitimate desire fall, generally speaking, under one
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of these three categories:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 1. The knowledge of things through their primary causes.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 2. The government of the passions, or the acquirement of the habit of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 3. Secure and healthy life.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (22) The means which most directly conduce towards the first two of these
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ends, and which may be considered their proximate and efficient causes are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contained in human nature itself, so that their acquisition hinges only on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our own power, and on the laws of human nature. (23) It may be concluded
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that these gifts are not peculiar to any nation, but have always been shared
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the whole human race, unless, indeed, we would indulge the dream that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature formerly created men of different kinds. (24) But the means which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conduce to security and health are chiefly in external circumstance, and are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called the gifts of fortune because they depend chiefly on objective causes
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of which we are ignorant; for a fool may be almost as liable to happiness
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or unhappiness as a wise man. (25) Nevertheless, human management and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: watchfulness can greatly assist towards living in security and warding off
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the injuries of our fellow-men, and even of beasts. (26) Reason and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: experience show no more certain means of attaining this object than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the formation of a society with fixed laws, the occupation of a strip of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: territory and the concentration of all forces, as it were, into one body,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that is the social body. (27) Now for forming and preserving a society, no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ordinary ability and care is required: that society will be most
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: secure, most stable, and least liable to reverses, which is founded and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: directed by far-seeing and careful men; while, on the other hand, a society
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constituted by men without trained skill, depends in a great measure on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fortune, and is less constant. (28) If, in spite of all, such a society
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lasts a long time, it is owing to some other directing influence than its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own; if it overcomes great perils and its affairs prosper, it will perforce
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: marvel at and adore the guiding Spirit of God (in so far, that is, as God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: works through hidden means, and not through the nature and mind of man),
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for everything happens to it unexpectedly and contrary to anticipation, it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may even be said and thought to be by miracle. (29) Nations, then, are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinguished from one another in respect to the social organization and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws under which they live and are governed; the Hebrew nation was not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chosen by God in respect to its wisdom nor its tranquillity of mind, but in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: respect to its social organization and the good fortune with which it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obtained supremacy and kept it so many years. (30) This is abundantly clear
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from Scripture. Even a cursory perusal will show us that the only respects
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in which the Hebrews surpassed other nations, are in their successful
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conduct of matters relating to government, and in their surmounting great
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perils solely by God's external aid; in other ways they were on a par with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their fellows, and God was equally gracious to all. (31) For in respect to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intellect (as we have shown in the last chapter) they held very ordinary
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ideas about God and nature, so that they cannot have been God's chosen in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this respect; nor were they so chosen in respect of virtue and the true
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: life, for here again they, with the exception of a very few elect, were on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an equality with other nations: therefore their choice and vocation
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consisted only in the temporal happiness and advantages of independent rule.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (32) In fact, we do not see that God promised anything beyond this to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: patriarchs [Endnote 4] or their successors; in the law no other reward is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: offered for obedience than the continual happiness of an independent
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commonwealth and other goods of this life; while, on the other hand, against
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contumacy and the breaking of the covenant is threatened the downfall of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commonwealth and great hardships. (33) Nor is this to be wondered at; for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the ends of every social organization and commonwealth are (as appears from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what we have said, and as we will explain more at length hereafter) security
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and comfort; a commonwealth can only exist by the laws being binding on all.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (34) If all the members of a state wish to disregard the law, by that very
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact they dissolve the state and destroy the commonwealth. (35) Thus, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only reward which could be promised to the Hebrews for continued obedience
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the law was security [Endnote 5] and its attendant advantages, while no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: surer punishment could be threatened for disobedience, than the ruin of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state and the evils which generally follow therefrom, in addition to such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further consequences as might accrue to the Jews in particular from the ruin
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of their especial state. (36) But there is no need here to go into this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: point at more length. (37) I will only add that the laws of the Old
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Testament were revealed and ordained to the Jews only, for as God chose them
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in respect to the special constitution of their society and government, they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must, of course, have had special laws. (38) Whether God ordained special
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws for other nations also, and revealed Himself to their lawgivers
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophetically, that is, under the attributes by which the latter were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accustomed to imagine Him, I cannot sufficiently determine. (39) It is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evident from Scripture itself that other nations acquired supremacy and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: particular laws by the external aid of God; witness only the two following
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passages:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (40) In Genesis xiv:18, 19, 20, it is related that Melchisedek was king of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jerusalem and priest of the Most High God, that in exercise of his priestly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: functions he blessed Abraham, and that Abraham the beloved of the Lord gave
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to this priest of God a tithe of all his spoils. (41) This sufficiently
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shows that before He founded the Israelitish nation God constituted kings
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and priests in Jerusalem, and ordained for them rites and laws. (42) Whether
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: He did so prophetically is, as I have said, not sufficiently clear; but I am
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sure of this, that Abraham, whilst he sojourned in the city, lived
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: scrupulously according to these laws, for Abraham had received no special
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rites from God; and yet it is stated (Gen. xxvi:5), that he observed the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: worship, the precepts, the statutes, and the laws of God, which must be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interpreted to mean the worship, the statutes, the precepts, and the laws of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: king Melchisedek. (43) Malachi chides the Jews as follows (i:10-11.): "Who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is there among you that will shut the doors? [of the Temple]; neither do ye
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: kindle fire on mine altar for nought. (44) I have no pleasure in you, saith
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Lord of Hosts. (45) For from the rising of the sun, even until the going
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: down of the same My Name shall be great among the Gentiles; and in every
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: place incense shall be offered in My Name, and a pure offering; for My Name
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is great among the heathen, saith the Lord of Hosts." (46) These words,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which, unless we do violence to them, could only refer to the current
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: period, abundantly testify that the Jews of that time were not more beloved
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by God than other nations, that God then favoured other nations with more
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miracles than He vouchsafed to the Jews, who had then partly recovered their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: empire without miraculous aid; and, lastly, that the Gentiles possessed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rites and ceremonies acceptable to God. (47) But I pass over these points
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lightly: it is enough for my purpose to have shown that the election of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jews had regard to nothing but temporal physical happiness and freedom, in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other words, autonomous government, and to the manner and means by which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they obtained it; consequently to the laws in so far as they were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary to the preservation of that special government; and, lastly, to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the manner in which they were revealed. In regard to other matters, wherein
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man's true happiness consists, they were on a par with the rest of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nations.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (48) When, therefore, it is said in Scripture (Deut. iv:7) that the Lord is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not so nigh to any other nation as He is to the Jews, reference is only made
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to their government, and to the period when so many miracles happened to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them, for in respect of intellect and virtue - that is, in respect of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blessedness - God was, as we have said already, and are now demonstrating,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equally gracious to all. (49) Scripture itself bears testimony to this fact,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for the Psalmist says (cxlv:18), "The Lord is near unto all them that call
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: upon Him, to all that call upon Him in truth." (50) So in the same Psalm,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: verse 9, "The Lord is good to all, and His tender mercies are over all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: His works." In Ps. xxxiii:16, it is clearly stated that God has granted to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all men the same intellect, in these words, He fashioneth their hearts
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: alike." The heart was considered by the Hebrews, as I suppose everyone
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knows, to be the seat of the soul and the intellect.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (51) Lastly, from Job xxxviii:28, it is plain that God had ordained for the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whole human race the law to reverence God, to keep from evil doing, or to do
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: well, and that Job, although a Gentile, was of all men most acceptable to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, because he exceeded all in piety and religion. (52) Lastly, from Jonah
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: iv:2, it is very evident that, not only to the Jews but to all men, God was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gracious, merciful, long- suffering, and of great goodness, and repented Him
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the evil, for Jonah says: "Therefore I determined to flee before unto
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Tarshish, for I know that Thou art a gracious God, and merciful, slow to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anger, and of great kindness," &c., and that, therefore, God would pardon
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Ninevites. (53) We conclude, therefore (inasmuch as God is to all men
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equally gracious, and the Hebrews were only, chosen by him in respect to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their social organization and government), that the individual Jew, taken
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: apart from his social organization and government, possessed no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gift of God above other men, and that there was no difference between Jew
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and Gentile. (54) As it is a fact that God is equally gracious, merciful,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the rest, to all men; and as the function of the prophet was to teach
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men not so much the laws of their country, as true virtue, and to exhort
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them thereto, it is not to be doubted that all nations possessed prophets,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and that the prophetic gift was not peculiar to the Jews. (55) Indeed,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: history, both profane and sacred, bears witness to the fact. (56) Although,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the sacred histories of the Old Testament, it is not evident that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other nations had as many prophets as the Hebrews, or that any Gentile
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophet was expressly sent by God to the nations, this does not affect the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: question, for the Hebrews were careful to record their own affairs, not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those of other nations. (57) It suffices, then, that we find in the Old
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Testament Gentiles, and uncircumcised, as Noah, Enoch, Abimelech,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Balaam, &c., exercising prophetic gifts; further, that Hebrew prophets were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sent by God, not only to their own nation but to many others also. (58)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ezekiel prophesied to all the nations then known; Obadiah to none, that we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are aware of, save the Idumeans; and Jonah was chiefly the prophet to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Ninevites. (59) Isaiah bewails and predicts the calamities, and hails the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: restoration not only of the Jews but also of other nations, for he says
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (chap. xvi:9), "Therefore I will bewail Jazer with weeping;" and in chap.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xix. he foretells first the calamities and then the restoration of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Egyptians (see verses 19, 20, 21, 25), saying that God shall send them a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Saviour to free them, that the Lord shall be known in Egypt, and, further,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the Egyptians shall worship God with sacrifice and oblation; and, at
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: last, he calls that nation the blessed Egyptian people of God; all of which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: particulars are specially noteworthy.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (60) Jeremiah is called, not the prophet of the Hebrew nation, but simply
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the prophet of the nations (see Jer:i.5). (61) He also mournfully foretells
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the calamities of the nations, and predicts their restoration, for he says
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (xlviii:31) of the Moabites, "Therefore will I howl for Moab, and I will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cry out for all Moab" (verse 36), "and therefore mine heart shall sound
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for Moab like pipes;" in the end he prophesies their restoration, as also
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the restoration of the Egyptians, Ammonites, and Elamites. (62) Wherefore it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is beyond doubt that other nations also, like the Jews, had their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophets, who prophesied to them.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (63) Although Scripture only, makes mention of one man, Balaam, to whom the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: future of the Jews and the other nations was revealed, we must not suppose
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that Balaam prophesied only once, for from the narrative itself it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: abundantly clear that he had long previously been famous for prophesy and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other Divine gifts. (64) For when Balak bade him to come to him, he said
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Num. xxii:6), "For I know that he whom thou blessest is blessed, and he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whom thou cursest is cursed." (65) Thus we see that he possessed the gift
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which God had bestowed on Abraham. Further, as accustomed to prophesy,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Balaam bade the messengers wait for him till the will of the Lord was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revealed to him. (66) When he prophesied, that is, when he interpreted
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the true mind of God, he was wont to say this of himself: "He hath said,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which heard the words of God and knew the knowledge of the Most High, which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: saw the vision of the Almighty falling into a trance, but having his eyes
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: open." (67) Further, after he had blessed the Hebrews by the command of God,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he began (as was his custom) to prophesy to other nations, and to predict
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their future; all of which abundantly shows that he had always been a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophet, or had often prophesied, and (as we may also remark here) possessed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that which afforded the chief certainty to prophets of the truth of their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophecy, namely, a mind turned wholly to what is right and good, for he did
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not bless those whom he wished to bless, nor curse those whom he wished to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: curse, as Balak supposed, but only those whom God wished to be blessed or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cursed. (68) Thus he answered Balak: "If Balak should give me his house full
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of silver and gold, I cannot go beyond the commandment of the Lord to do
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: either good or bad of my own mind; but what the Lord saith, that will I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: speak." (69) As for God being angry with him in the way, the same happened
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to Moses when he set out to Egypt by the command of the Lord; and as to his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: receiving money for prophesying, Samuel did the same (1 Sam. ix:7, 8); if in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anyway he sinned, "there is not a just man upon earth that doeth good and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sinneth not," Eccles. vii:20. (Vide 2 Epist. Peter ii:15, 16, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jude 5:11.)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (70) His speeches must certainly have had much weight with God, and His
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power for cursing must assuredly have been very great from the number of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: times that we find stated in Scripture, in proof of God's great mercy to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jews, that God would not hear Balaam, and that He changed the cursing to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blessing (see Deut. xxiii:6, Josh. xxiv:10, Neh. xiii:2). (71) Wherefore he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was without doubt most acceptable to God, for the speeches and cursings of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the wicked move God not at all. (72) As then he was a true prophet, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nevertheless Joshua calls him a soothsayer or augur, it is certain that this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: title had an honourable signification, and that those whom the Gentiles
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called augurs and soothsayers were true prophets, while those whom Scripture
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: often accuses and condemns were false soothsayers, who deceived the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Gentiles as false prophets deceived the Jews; indeed, this is made evident
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from other passages in the Bible, whence we conclude that the gift of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophecy was not peculiar to the Jews, but common to all nations. (73) The
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Pharisees, however, vehemently contend that this Divine gift was peculiar to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their nation, and that the other nations foretold the future (what will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: superstition invent next?) by some unexplained diabolical faculty. (74) The
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: principal passage of Scripture which they cite, by way of confirming their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: theory with its authority, is Exodus xxxiii:16, where Moses says to God,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "For wherein shall it be known here that I and Thy people have found grace
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in Thy sight? is it not in that Thou goest with us? so shall we be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: separated, I and Thy people, from all the people that are upon the face of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the earth." (75) From this they would infer that Moses asked of God that He
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should be present to the Jews, and should reveal Himself to them
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophetically; further, that He should grant this favour to no other nation.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (76) It is surely absurd that Moses should have been jealous of God's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: presence among the Gentiles, or that he should have dared to ask any such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing. (77) The act is, as Moses knew that the disposition and spirit of his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nation was rebellious, he clearly saw that they could not carry out what
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they had begun without very great miracles and special external aid from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God; nay, that without such aid they must necessarily perish: as it was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evident that God wished them to be preserved, he asked for this special
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external aid. (78) Thus he says (Ex. xxxiv:9), "If now I have found grace in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thy sight, 0 Lord, let my Lord, I pray Thee, go among us; for it is a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stiffnecked people." (79) The reason, therefore, for his seeking special
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external aid from God was the stiffneckedness of the people, and it is made
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: still more plain, that he asked for nothing beyond this special external aid
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by God's answer - for God answered at once (verse 10 of the same chapter) -
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "Behold, I make a covenant: before all Thy people I will do marvels, such as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have not been done in all the earth, nor in any nation." (80) Therefore
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses had in view nothing beyond the special election of the Jews, as I have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explained it, and made no other request to God. (81) I confess that in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Paul's Epistle to the Romans, I find another text which carries more weight,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: namely, where Paul seems to teach a different doctrine from that here set
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: down, for he there says (Rom. iii:1): "What advantage then hath the Jew? or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what profit is there of circumcision? (82) Much every way: chiefly, because
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that unto them were committed the oracles of God."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (83) But if we look to the doctrine which Paul especially desired to teach,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we shall find nothing repugnant to our present contention; on the contrary,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his doctrine is the same as ours, for he says (Rom. iii:29) "that God is the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God of the Jews and of the Gentiles, and" (ch. ii:25, 26) "But,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if thou be a breaker of the law, thy circumcision is made uncircumcision.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (84) Therefore if the uncircumcision keep the righteousness of the law,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shall not his uncircumcision be counted for circumcision?" (85) Further, in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chap. iv:verse 9, he says that all alike, Jew and Gentile, were under sin,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and that without commandment and law there is no sin. (86) Wherefore it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: most evident that to all men absolutely was revealed the law under which all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lived - namely, the law which has regard only to true virtue, not the law
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: established in respect to, and in the formation of a particular state and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adapted to the disposition of a particular people. (87) Lastly, Paul
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concludes that since God is the God of all nations, that is, is equally
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gracious to all, and since all men equally live under the law and under sin,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so also to all nations did God send His Christ, to free all men equally from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the bondage of the law, that they should no more do right by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: command of the law, but by the constant determination of their hearts. (88)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: So that Paul teaches exactly the same as ourselves. (89) When, therefore, he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: says "To the Jews only were entrusted the oracles of God," we must either
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand that to them only were the laws entrusted in writing, while they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were given to other nations merely in revelation and conception, or else (as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: none but Jews would object to the doctrine he desired to advance) that Paul
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was answering only in accordance with the understanding and current ideas of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Jews, for in respect to teaching things which he had partly seen, partly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: heard, he was to the Greeks a Greek, and to the Jews a Jew.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (90) It now only remains to us to answer the arguments of those who would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persuade themselves that the election of the Jews was not temporal, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: merely in respect of their commonwealth, but eternal; for, they say, we see
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Jews after the loss of their commonwealth, and after being scattered so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: many years and separated from all other nations, still surviving, which is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without parallel among other peoples, and further the Scriptures seem to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: teach that God has chosen for Himself the Jews for ever, so that though they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have lost their commonwealth, they still nevertheless remain God's elect.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (91) The passages which they think teach most clearly this eternal election, are chiefly:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (1.) Jer. xxxi:36, where the prophet testifies that the seed of Israel
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shall for ever remain the nation of God, comparing them with the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stability of the heavens and nature;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (2.) Ezek. xx:32, where the prophet seems to intend that though the Jews
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wanted after the help afforded them to turn their backs on the worship of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Lord, that God would nevertheless gather them together again from all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the lands in which they were dispersed, and lead them to the wilderness of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the peoples - as He had led their fathers to the wilderness of the land of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Egypt - and would at length, after purging out from among them the rebels
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and transgressors, bring them thence to his Holy mountain, where the whole
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: house of Israel should worship Him. Other passages are also cited,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: especially by the Pharisees, but I think I shall satisfy everyone if I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: answer these two, and this I shall easily accomplish after showing from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scripture itself that God chose not the Hebrews for ever, but only on the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: condition under which He had formerly chosen the Canaanites, for these last,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as we have shown, had priests who religiously worshipped God, and whom God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at length rejected because of their luxury, pride, and corrupt worship.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (92) Moses (Lev. xviii:27) warned the Israelites that they be not polluted
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with whoredoms, lest the land spue them out as it had spued out the nations
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who had dwelt there before, and in Deut. viii:19, 20, in the plainest terms
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: He threatens their total ruin, for He says, "I testify against you that ye
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shall surely perish. (93) As the nations which the Lord destroyeth before
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: your face, so shall ye perish." In like manner many other passages are found
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the law which expressly show that God chose the Hebrews neither
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolutely nor for ever. (94) If, then, the prophets foretold for them a new
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: covenant of the knowledge of God, love, and grace, such a promise is easily
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proved to be only made to the elect, for Ezekiel in the chapter which we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have just quoted expressly says that God will separate from them the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rebellious and transgressors, and Zephaniah (iii:12, 13), says that "God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will take away the proud from the midst of them, and leave the poor." (95)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Now, inasmuch as their election has regard to true virtue, it is not to be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought that it was promised to the Jews alone to the exclusion of others,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but we must evidently believe that the true Gentile prophets (and every
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nation, as we have shown, possessed such) promised the same to the faithful
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of their own people, who were thereby comforted. (96) Wherefore this eternal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: covenant of the knowledge of God and love is universal, as is clear,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: moreover, from Zeph. iii:10, 11: no difference in this respect can be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: admitted between Jew and Gentile, nor did the former enjoy any special
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: election beyond that which we have pointed out.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (97) When the prophets, in speaking of this election which regards only true
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue, mixed up much concerning sacrifices and ceremonies, and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rebuilding of the temple and city, they wished by such figurative
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: expressions, after the manner and nature of prophecy, to expound matters
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: spiritual, so as at the same time to show to the Jews, whose prophets they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were, the true restoration of the state and of the temple to be expected
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: about the time of Cyrus.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (98) At the present time, therefore, there is absolutely nothing which the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jews can arrogate to themselves beyond other people.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (99) As to their continuance so long after dispersion and the loss of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: empire, there is nothing marvellous in it, for they so separated themselves
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from every other nation as to draw down upon themselves universal hate, not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only by their outward rites, rites conflicting with those of other nations,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but also by the sign of circumcision which they most scrupulously observe.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (100) That they have been preserved in great measure by Gentile hatred,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: experience demonstrates. (101) When the king of Spain formerly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compelled the Jews to embrace the State religion or to go into exile, a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: large number of Jews accepted Catholicism. (102) Now, as these renegades
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were admitted to all the native privileges of Spaniards, and deemed worthy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of filling all honourable offices, it came to pass that they straightway
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: became so intermingled with the Spaniards as to leave of themselves no relic
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or remembrance. (103) But exactly the opposite happened to those whom the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: king of Portugal compelled to become Christians, for they always, though
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: converted, lived apart, inasmuch as they were considered unworthy of any
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: civic honours.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (104) The sign of circumcision is, as I think, so important, that I could
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persuade myself that it alone would preserve the nation for ever. (105) Nay,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I would go so far as to believe that if the foundations of their religion
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have not emasculated their minds they may even, if occasion offers, so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: changeable are human affairs, raise up their empire afresh, and that God may
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a second time elect them.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (106) Of such a possibility we have a very famous example in the Chinese.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (107) They, too, have some distinctive mark on their heads which they most
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: scrupulously observe, and by which they keep themselves apart from everyone
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: else, and have thus kept themselves during so many thousand years that they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: far surpass all other nations in antiquity. (108) They have not always
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: retained empire, but they have recovered it when lost, and doubtless will do
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so again after the spirit of the Tartars becomes relaxed through the luxury
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of riches and pride.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
