text: (109) Lastly, if any one wishes to maintain that the Jews, from this or from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any other cause, have been chosen by God for ever, I will not gainsay him if
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he will admit that this choice, whether temporary or eternal, has no regard,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in so far as it is peculiar to the Jews, to aught but dominion and physical
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: advantages (for by such alone can one nation be distinguished from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another), whereas in regard to intellect and true virtue, every nation is on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a par with the rest, and God has not in these respects chosen one people
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rather than another.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: CHAPTER IV. - OF THE DIVINE LAW.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (1) The word law, taken in the abstract, means that by which an individual,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or all things, or as many things as belong to a particular species, act in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one and the same fixed and definite manner, which manner depends either on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural necessity or on human decree. (2) A law which depends on natural
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity is one which necessarily follows from the nature, or from the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definition of the thing in question; a law which depends on human decree,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and which is more correctly called an ordinance, is one which men have laid
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: down for themselves and others in order to live more safely or conveniently,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or from some similar reason.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (3) For example, the law that all bodies impinging on lesser bodies, lose as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: much of their own motion as they communicate to the latter is a universal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: law of all bodies, and depends on natural necessity. (4) So, too, the law
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that a man in remembering one thing, straightway remembers another either
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: like it, or which he had perceived simultaneously with it, is a law which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily follows from the nature of man. (5) But the law that men must
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: yield, or be compelled to yield, somewhat of their natural right, and that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they bind themselves to live in a certain way, depends on human decree. (6)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Now, though I freely admit that all things are predetermined by universal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural laws to exist and operate in a given, fixed, and definite
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manner, I still assert that the laws I have just mentioned depend on human
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: decree.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (1.) (7) Because man, in so far as he is a part of nature, constitutes a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: part of the power of nature. (8) Whatever, therefore, follows necessarily
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from the necessity of human nature (that is, from nature herself, in so far
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as we conceive of her as acting through man) follows, even though it be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily, from human power. (9) Hence the sanction of such laws may very
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: well be said to depend on man's decree, for it principally depends on the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of the human mind; so that the human mind in respect to its perception
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of things as true and false, can readily be conceived as without such laws,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but not without necessary law as we have just defined it.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (2.) (10) I have stated that these laws depend on human decree because it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: well to define and explain things by their proximate causes. (11) The
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: general consideration of fate and the concatenation of causes would aid us
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: very little in forming and arranging our ideas concerning particular
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: questions. (12) Let us add that as to the actual coordination and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concatenation of things, that is how things are ordained and linked
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: together, we are obviously ignorant; therefore, it is more profitable for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right living, nay, it is necessary for us to consider things as contingent.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (13) So much about law in the abstract.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (14) Now the word law seems to be only applied to natural phenomena by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: analogy, and is commonly taken to signify a command which men can either
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obey or neglect, inasmuch as it restrains human nature within certain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: originally exceeded limits, and therefore lays down no rule beyond human
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strength. (15) Thus it is expedient to define law more particularly as a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: plan of life laid down by man for himself or others with a certain object.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16) However, as the true object of legislation is only perceived by a few,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and most men are almost incapable of grasping it, though they live under its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conditions, legislators, with a view to exacting general obedience, have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wisely put forward another object, very different from that which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily follows from the nature of law: they promise to the observers of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the law that which the masses chiefly desire, and threaten its violators
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with that which they chiefly fear: thus endeavouring to restrain the masses,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as far as may be, like a horse with a curb; whence it follows that the word
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: law is chiefly applied to the modes of life enjoined on men by the sway of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: others; hence those who obey the law are said to live under it and to be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under compulsion. (17) In truth, a man who renders everyone their due
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because he fears the gallows, acts under the sway and compulsion of others,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and cannot be called just. (18) But a man who does the same from a knowledge
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the true reason for laws and their necessity, acts from a firm purpose
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and of his own accord, and is therefore properly called just. (19) This, I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: take it, is Paul's meaning when he says, that those who live under the law
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be justified through the law, for justice, as commonly defined, is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the constant and perpetual will to render every man his due. (20) Thus
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Solomon says (Prov. xxi:15), "It is a joy to the just to do judgment," but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the wicked fear.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (21) Law, then, being a plan of living which men have for a certain object
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laid down for themselves or others, may, as it seems, be divided into human
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: law and Divine law. {But both are opposite sides of the same coin}
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (22) By human law I mean a plan of living which serves only to render life
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the state secure. (23) By Divine law I mean that which only regards the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: highest good, in other words, the true knowledge of God and love.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (24) I call this law Divine because of the nature of the highest good, which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I will here shortly explain as clearly as I can.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (25) Inasmuch as the intellect is the best part of our being, it is evident
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that we should make every effort to perfect it as far as possible if we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desire to search for what is really profitable to us. (26) For in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intellectual perfection the highest good should consist. (27) Now, since all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our knowledge, and the certainty which removes every doubt, depend solely on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the knowledge of God;- firstly, because without God nothing can exist or be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived; secondly, because so long as we have no clear and distinct idea
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God we may remain in universal doubt - it follows that our highest good
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and perfection also depend solely on the knowledge of God. (28) Further,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: since without God nothing can exist or be conceived, it is evident that all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural phenomena involve and express the conception of God as far as their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence and perfection extend, so that we have greater and more perfect
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of God in proportion to our knowledge of natural phenomena:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conversely (since the knowledge of an effect through its cause is the same
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing as the knowledge of a particular property of a cause) the greater our
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of natural phenomena, the more perfect is our knowledge of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of God (which is the cause of all things). (29) So, then, our
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: highest good not only depends on the knowledge of God, but wholly consists
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therein; and it further follows that man is perfect or the reverse in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion to the nature and perfection of the object of his special desire;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hence the most perfect and the chief sharer in the highest blessedness is he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who prizes above all else, and takes especial delight in, the intellectual
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of God, the most perfect Being.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (30) Hither, then, our highest good and our highest blessedness aim -
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: namely, to the knowledge and love of God; therefore the means demanded by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this aim of all human actions, that is, by God in so far as the idea of him
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is in us, may be called the commands of God, because they proceed, as it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were, from God Himself, inasmuch as He exists in our minds, and the plan of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: life which has regard to this aim may be fitly called the law of God.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (31) The nature of the means, and the plan of life which this aim demands,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: how the foundations of the best states follow its lines, and how men's life
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is conducted, are questions pertaining to general ethics. (32) Here I only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (33) As the love of God is man's highest happiness and blessedness, and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ultimate end and aim of all human actions, it follows that he alone lives by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Divine law who loves God not from fear of punishment, or from love of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any other object, such as sensual pleasure, fame, or the like; but solely
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because he has knowledge of God, or is convinced that the knowledge and love
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God is the highest good. (34) The sum and chief precept, then, of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine law is to love God as the highest good, namely, as we have said, not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from fear of any pains and penalties, or from the love of any other object
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in which we desire to take pleasure. (35) The idea of God lays down
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the rule that God is our highest good - in other words, that the knowledge
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and love of God is the ultimate aim to which all our actions should be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: directed. (36) The worldling cannot understand these things, they appear
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foolishness to him, because he has too meager a knowledge of God, and also
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because in this highest good he can discover nothing which he can handle or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eat, or which affects the fleshly appetites wherein he chiefly delights, for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hand, who know that they possess no greater gift than intellect and sound
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason, will doubtless accept what I have said without question.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (38) We have now explained that wherein the Divine law chiefly consists, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what are human laws, namely, all those which have a different aim
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unless they have been ratified by revelation, for in this respect also
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: disposition and particular preservation of a single people, may yet be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called a law of God or Divine law, inasmuch as we believe that it was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ratified by prophetic insight. (39) If we consider the nature of natural
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine law as we have just explained it, we shall see:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (40) I.- That it is universal or common to all men, for we have deduced it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from universal human nature.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (41) II. That it does not depend on the truth of any historical narrative
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whatsoever, for inasmuch as this natural Divine law is comprehended solely
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the consideration of human nature, it is plain that we can conceive it as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existing as well in Adam as in any other man, as well in a man living among
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his fellows, as in a man who lives by himself.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (42) The truth of a historical narrative, however assured, cannot give us
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the knowledge nor consequently the love of God, for love of God springs from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of Him, and knowledge of Him should be derived from general ideas,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in themselves certain and known, so that the truth of a historical narrative
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is very far from being a necessary requisite for our attaining our highest
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (43) Still, though the truth of histories cannot give us the knowledge and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love of God, I do not deny that reading them is very useful with a view to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: life in the world, for the more we have observed and known of men's customs
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and circumstances, which are best revealed by their actions, the more warily
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we shall be able to order our lives among them, and so far as reason
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dictates to adapt our actions to their dispositions.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (44) III. We see that this natural Divine law does not demand the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: performance of ceremonies - that is, actions in themselves indifferent,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which are called good from the fact of their institution, or actions
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: symbolizing something profitable for salvation, or (if one prefers this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definition) actions of which the meaning surpasses human understanding. (45)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: The natural light of reason does not demand anything which it is itself
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unable to supply, but only such as it can very clearly show to be good, or a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: means to our blessedness. (46) Such things as are good simply because they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have been commanded or instituted, or as being symbols of something good,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are mere shadows which cannot be reckoned among actions that are the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: offsprings as it were, or fruit of a sound mind and of intellect. (47) There
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is no need for me to go into this now in more detail.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (48) IV. Lastly, we see that the highest reward of the Divine law is the law
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself, namely, to know God and to love Him of our free choice, and with an
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: undivided and fruitful spirit; while its penalty is the absence of these
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things, and being in bondage to the flesh - that is, having an inconstant
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and wavering spirit.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (49) These points being noted, I must now inquire:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (50) I. Whether by the natural light of reason we can conceive of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God as a law-giver or potentate ordaining laws for men?
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (51) II. What is the teaching of Holy Writ concerning this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural light of reason and natural law?
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (52) III. With what objects were ceremonies formerly instituted?
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (53) IV. Lastly, what is the good gained by knowing the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sacred histories and believing them?
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (54) Of the first two I will treat in this chapter, of the remaining two
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the following one.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (55) Our conclusion about the first is easily deduced from the nature of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God's will, which is only distinguished from His understanding in relation
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to our intellect - that is, the will and the understanding of God are in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reality one and the same, and are only distinguished in relation to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our thoughts which we form concerning God's understanding. (56) For
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instance, if we are only looking to the fact that the nature of a triangle
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is from eternity contained in the Divine nature as an eternal verity, we say
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that God possesses the idea of a triangle, or that He understands the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of a triangle; but if afterwards we look to the fact that the nature
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of a triangle is thus contained in the Divine nature, solely by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity of the Divine nature, and not by the necessity of the nature and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence of a triangle - in fact, that the necessity of a triangle's essence
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and nature, in so far as they are conceived of as eternal verities, depends
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solely on the necessity of the Divine nature and intellect, we then style
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God's will or decree, that which before we styled His intellect. (57)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Wherefore we make one and the same affirmation concerning God when we say
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that He has from eternity decreed that three angles of a triangle are equal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to two right angles, as when we say that He has understood it.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (58) Hence the affirmations and the negations of God always involve
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity or truth; so that, for example, if God said to Adam that He did
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not wish him to eat of the tree of knowledge of good and evil, it would have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: involved a contradiction that Adam should have been able to eat of it, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would therefore have been impossible that he should have so eaten, for the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine command would have involved an eternal necessity and truth. (59) But
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: since Scripture nevertheless narrates that God did give this command to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Adam, and yet that none the less Adam ate of the tree, we must perforce say
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that God revealed to Adam the evil which would surely follow if he should
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eat of the tree, but did not disclose that such evil would of necessity
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: come to pass. (60) Thus it was that Adam took the revelation to be not an
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternal and necessary truth, but a law - that is, an ordinance followed by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gain or loss, not depending necessarily on the nature of the act performed,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but solely on the will and absolute power of some potentate, so that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revelation in question was solely in relation to Adam, and solely through
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his lack of knowledge a law, and God was, as it were, a lawgiver and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: potentate. (61) From the same cause, namely, from lack of knowledge, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Decalogue in relation to the Hebrews was a law, for since they knew not the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of God as an eternal truth, they must have taken as a law that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which was revealed to them in the Decalogue, namely, that God exists, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that God only should be worshipped. (62) But if God had spoken to them
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without the intervention of any bodily means, immediately they would have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perceived it not as a law, but as an eternal truth.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (63) What we have said about the Israelites and Adam, applies also to all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the prophets who wrote laws in God's name - they did not adequately conceive
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God's decrees as eternal truths. (64) For instance, we must say of Moses
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that from revelation, from the basis of what was revealed to him, he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perceived the method by which the Israelitish nation could best be united in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a particular territory, and could form a body politic or state, and further
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that he perceived the method by which that nation could best be constrained
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to obedience; but he did not perceive, nor was it revealed to him, that this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: method was absolutely the best, nor that the obedience of the people in a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain strip of territory would necessarily imply the end he had in view.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (65) Wherefore he perceived these things not as eternal truths, but as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: precepts and ordinances, and he ordained them as laws of God, and thus it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: came to be that he conceived God as a ruler, a legislator, a king, as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: merciful, just, &c., whereas such qualities are simply attributes of human
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, and utterly alien from the nature of the Deity. (66)Thus much we may
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affirm of the prophets who wrote laws in the name of God; but we must not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affirm it of Christ, for Christ, although He too seems to have written laws
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the name of God, must be taken to have had a clear and adequate
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perception, for Christ was not so much a prophet as the mouthpiece of God.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (67) For God made revelations to mankind through Christ as He had before
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: done through angels - that is, a created voice, visions, &c. (68) It would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be as unreasonable to say that God had accommodated his revelations to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: opinions of Christ as that He had before accommodated them to the opinions
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of angels (that is, of a created voice or visions) as matters to be revealed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the prophets, a wholly absurd hypothesis. (69) Moreover, Christ was sent
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to teach not only the Jews but the whole human race, and therefore it was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not enough that His mind should be accommodated to the opinions the Jews
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: alone, but also to the opinion and fundamental teaching common to the whole
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human race - in other words, to ideas universal and true. (70) Inasmuch as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God revealed Himself to Christ, or to Christ's mind immediately, and not as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the prophets through words and symbols, we must needs suppose that Christ
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perceived truly what was revealed, in other words, He understood it, for a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: matter is understood when it is perceived simply by the mind without words
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or symbols.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (71) Christ, then, perceived (truly and adequately) what was revealed, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if He ever proclaimed such revelations as laws, He did so because of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ignorance and obstinacy of the people, acting in this respect the part of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God; inasmuch as He accommodated Himself to the comprehension of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people, and though He spoke somewhat more clearly than the other prophets,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: yet He taught what was revealed obscurely, and generally through parables,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: especially when He was speaking to those to whom it was not yet given to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand the kingdom of heaven. (See Matt. xiii:10, &c.) (72) To those to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whom it was given to understand the mysteries of heaven, He doubtless taught
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: His doctrines as eternal truths, and did not lay them down as laws, thus
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: freeing the minds of His hearers from the bondage of that law which He
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further confirmed and established. (73) Paul apparently points to this more
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than once (e.g. Rom. vii:6, and iii:28), though he never himself seems to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wish to speak openly, but, to quote his own words (Rom. iii:6, and vi:19),
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "merely humanly." (74) This he expressly states when he calls God just, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it was doubtless in concession to human weakness that he attributes mercy,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: grace, anger, and similar qualities to God, adapting his language to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: popular mind, or, as he puts it (1 Cor. iii:1, 2), to carnal men. (75) In
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Rom. ix:18, he teaches undisguisedly that God's auger and mercy depend not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on the actions of men, but on God's own nature or will; further, that no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one is justified by the works of the law, but only by faith, which he seems
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to identify with the full assent of the soul; lastly, that no one is blessed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unless he have in him the mind of Christ (Rom. viii:9), whereby he perceives
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the laws of God as eternal truths. (76) We conclude, therefore, that God is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: described as a lawgiver or prince, and styled just, merciful, &c., merely in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concession to popular understanding, and the imperfection of popular
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge; that in reality God acts and directs all things simply by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity of His nature and perfection, and that His decrees and volitions
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are eternal truths, and always involve necessity. (77) So much for the first
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: point which I wished to explain and demonstrate.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (78) Passing on to the second point, let us search the sacred pages for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their teaching concerning the light of nature and this Divine law. (79) The
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: first doctrine we find in the history of the first man, where it is narrated
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that God commanded Adam not to eat of the fruit of the tree of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of good and evil; this seems to mean that God commanded Adam to do
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and to seek after righteousness because it was good, not because the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary was evil: that is, to seek the good for its own sake, not from fear
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of evil. (80) We have seen that he who acts rightly from the true knowledge
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and love of right, acts with freedom and constancy, whereas he who acts from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear of evil, is under the constraint of evil, and acts in bondage under
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external control. (81) So that this commandment of God to Adam comprehends
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the whole Divine natural law, and absolutely agrees with the dictates of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: light of nature; nay, it would be easy to explain on this basis the whole
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: history or allegory of the first man. (82) But I prefer to pass over the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subject in silence, because, in the first place, I cannot be absolutely
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain that my explanation would be in accordance with the intention of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sacred writer; and, secondly, because many do not admit that this history is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an allegory, maintaining it to be a simple narrative of facts. (83) It will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be better, therefore, to adduce other passages of Scripture, especially such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as were written by him, who speaks with all the strength of his natural
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding, in which he surpassed all his contemporaries, and whose
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sayings are accepted by the people as of equal weight with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those of the prophets. (84) I mean Solomon, whose prudence and wisdom are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commended in Scripture rather than his piety and gift of prophecy. (85) Life
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being taken to mean the true life (as is evident from Deut. xxx:19), the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fruit of the understanding consists only in the true life, and its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absence constitutes punishment. (86) All this absolutely agrees with what
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was set out in our fourth point concerning natural law. (87) Moreover our
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: position that it is the well-spring of life, and that the intellect alone
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lays down laws for the wise, is plainly taught by, the sage, for he says
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Prov. xiii:14): "The law of the wise is a fountain of life" - that is, as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we gather from the preceding text, the understanding. (88) In chap. iii:13,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he expressly teaches that the understanding renders man blessed and happy,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and gives him true peace of mind. "Happy is the man that findeth wisdom, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the man that getteth understanding," for "Wisdom gives length of days, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: riches and honour; her ways are ways of pleasantness, and all her paths
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: peace" (xiiii:6, 17). (89) According to Solomon, therefore, it is only,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the wise who live in peace and equanimity, not like the wicked whose minds
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: drift hither and thither, and (as Isaiah says, chap. lvii:20) "are like the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: troubled sea, for them there is no peace."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (90) Lastly, we should especially note the passage in chap. ii. of Solomon's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proverbs which most clearly confirms our contention: "If thou criest after
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge, and liftest up thy voice for understanding . . . then shalt thou
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understand the fear of the Lord, and find the knowledge of God; for the Lord
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: giveth wisdom; out of His mouth cometh knowledge and understanding."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (91) These words clearly enunciate (1), that wisdom or intellect alone
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: teaches us to fear God wisely - that is, to worship Him truly; (2), that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wisdom and knowledge flow from God's mouth, and that God bestows on us this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gift; this we have already shown in proving that our understanding and our
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge depend on, spring from, and are perfected by the idea or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of God, and nothing else. (92) Solomon goes on to say in so many
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words that this knowledge contains and involves the true principles of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ethics and politics: "When wisdom entereth into thy heart, and knowledge is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasant to thy soul, discretion shall preserve thee, understanding shall
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: keep thee, then shalt thou understand righteousness, and judgment, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equity, yea every good path." (93) All of which is in obvious agreement with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural knowledge: for after we have come to the understanding of things,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and have tasted the excellence of knowledge, she teaches us ethics and true
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (94) Thus the happiness and the peace of him who cultivates his natural
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding lies, according to Solomon also, not so much under the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dominion of fortune (or God's external aid) as in inward personal virtue (or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God's internal aid), for the latter can to a great extent be preserved by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vigilance, right action, and thought.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (95) Lastly, we must by no means pass over the passage in Paul's Epistle to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Romans, i:20, in which he says: "For the invisible things of God from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the creation of the world are clearly seen, being understood by the things
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that are made, even His eternal power and Godhead; so that they are without
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: excuse, because, when they knew God, they glorified Him not as God, neither
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were they thankful." (96) These words clearly show that everyone can by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: light of nature clearly understand the goodness and the eternal divinity of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, and can thence know and deduce what they should seek for and what
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: avoid; wherefore the Apostle says that they are without excuse and cannot
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: plead ignorance, as they certainly might if it were a question of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: supernatural light and the incarnation, passion, and resurrection of Christ.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (97) "Wherefore," he goes on to say (ib. 24), "God gave them up to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: uncleanness through the lusts of their own hearts;" and so on, through the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest of the chapter, he describes the vices of ignorance, and sets them
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forth as the punishment of ignorance. (98) This obviously agrees with the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: verse of Solomon, already quoted, "The instruction of fools is folly," so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that it is easy to understand why Paul says that the wicked are without
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: excuse. (99) As every man sows so shall he reap: out of evil, evils
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily spring, unless they be wisely counteracted.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (100) Thus we see that Scripture literally approves of the light of natural
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason and the natural Divine law, and I have fulfilled the promises made at
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the beginning of this chapter.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: CHAPTER V. - OF THE CEREMONIAL LAW.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (1) In the foregoing chapter we have shown that the Divine law, which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: renders men truly blessed, and teaches them the true life, is universal to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all men; nay, we have so intimately deduced it from human nature that it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must be esteemed innate, and, as it were, ingrained in the human mind.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (2) But with regard to the ceremonial observances which were ordained in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Old Testament for the Hebrews only, and were so adapted to their state that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they could for the most part only be observed by the society as a whole and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not by each individual, it is evident that they formed no part of the Divine
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: law, and had nothing to do with blessedness and virtue, but had reference
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only to the election of the Hebrews, that is (as I have shown in Chap. II.),
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to their temporal bodily happiness and the tranquillity of their kingdom,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and that therefore they were only valid while that kingdom lasted. (3) If in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Old Testament they are spoken of as the law of God, it is only because
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they were founded on revelation, or a basis of revelation. (4) Still as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason, however sound, has little weight with ordinary theologians, I will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adduce the authority of Scripture for what I here assert, and will further
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: show, for the sake of greater clearness, why and how these ceremonials
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: served to establish and preserve the Jewish kingdom. (5) Isaiah teaches most
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: plainly that the Divine law in its strict sense signifies that universal law
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which consists in a true manner of life, and does not signify ceremonial
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: observances. (6) In chapter i:10, the prophet calls on his countrymen to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hearken to the Divine law as he delivers it, and first excluding all kinds
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of sacrifices and all feasts, he at length sums up the law in these few
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words, "Cease to do evil, learn to do well: seek judgment, relieve the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: oppressed." (7) Not less striking testimony is given in Psalm xl:7- 9, where
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Psalmist addresses God: "Sacrifice and offering Thou didst not desire;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mine ears hast Thou opened; burnt offering and sin-offering hast Thou not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: required; I delight to do Thy will, 0 my God; yea, Thy law is within my
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: heart." (8) Here the Psalmist reckons as the law of God only that which is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inscribed in his heart, and excludes ceremonies therefrom, for the latter
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are good and inscribed on the heart only from the fact of their institution,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and not because of their intrinsic value.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (9) Other passages of Scripture testify to the same truth, but these two
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will suffice. (10) We may also learn from the Bible that ceremonies are no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: aid to blessedness, but only have reference to the temporal prosperity of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the kingdom; for the rewards promised for their observance are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: merely temporal advantages and delights, blessedness being reserved for the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: universal Divine law. (11) In all the five books commonly attributed to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses nothing is promised, as I have said, beyond temporal benefits, such as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: honours, fame, victories, riches, enjoyments, and health. (12) Though many
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: moral precepts besides ceremonies are contained in these five books, they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appear not as moral doctrines universal to all men, but as commands
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: especially adapted to the understanding and character of the Hebrew people,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and as having reference only to the welfare of the kingdom. (13) For
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instance, Moses does not teach the Jews as a prophet not to kill or to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: steal, but gives these commandments solely as a lawgiver and judge; he does
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not reason out the doctrine, but affixes for its non-observance a penalty
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which may and very properly does vary in different nations. (14) So, too,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the command not to commit adultery is given merely with reference to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: welfare of the state; for if the moral doctrine had been intended, with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reference not only to the welfare of the state, but also to the tranquillity
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and blessedness of the individual, Moses would have condemned not merely the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: outward act, but also the mental acquiescence, as is done by Christ, Who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: taught only universal moral precepts, and for this cause promises a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: spiritual instead of a temporal reward. (15) Christ, as I have said, was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sent into the world, not to preserve the state nor to lay down laws, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: solely to teach the universal moral law, so we can easily understand that He
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wished in nowise to do away with the law of Moses, inasmuch as He introduced
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no new laws of His own - His sole care was to teach moral doctrines, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinguish them from the laws of the state; for the Pharisees, in their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ignorance, thought that the observance of the state law and the Mosaic law
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was the sum total of morality; whereas such laws merely had reference to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: public welfare, and aimed not so much at instructing the Jews as at keeping
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them under constraint. (16) But let us return to our subject, and cite other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passages of Scripture which set forth temporal benefits as rewards for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: observing the ceremonial law, and blessedness as reward for the universal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: law.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17) None of the prophets puts the point more clearly than Isaiah. (18.)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: After condemning hypocrisy he commends liberty and charity towards one's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: self and one's neighbours, and promises as a reward: "Then shall thy light
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: break forth as the morning, and thy health shall spring forth speedily, thy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: righteousness shall go before thee, and the glory of the Lord shall be thy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reward" (chap. lviii:8). (19) Shortly afterwards he commends the Sabbath,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and for a due observance of it, promises: "Then shalt thou delight thyself
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the Lord, and I will cause thee to ride upon the high places of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: earth, and feed thee with the heritage of Jacob thy father: for the mouth of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Lord has spoken it." (20) Thus the prophet for liberty bestowed, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: charitable works, promises a healthy mind in a healthy body, and the glory
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the Lord even after death; whereas, for ceremonial exactitude, he only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: promises security of rule, prosperity, and temporal happiness.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (21) In Psalms xv. and xxiv. no mention is made of ceremonies, but only of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: moral doctrines, inasmuch as there is no question of anything but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blessedness, and blessedness is symbolically promised: it is quite certain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the expressions, "the hill of God," and "His tents and the dwellers
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therein," refer to blessedness and security of soul, not to the actual mount
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Jerusalem and the tabernacle of Moses, for these latter were not dwelt in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by anyone, and only the sons of Levi ministered there. (22) Further, all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those sentences of Solomon to which I referred in the last chapter, for the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cultivation of the intellect and wisdom, promise true blessedness, for by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wisdom is the fear of God at length understood, and the knowledge of God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: found.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (23) That the Jews themselves were not bound to practise their ceremonial
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: observances after the destruction of their kingdom is evident from Jeremiah.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (24) For when the prophet saw and foretold that the desolation of the city
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was at hand, he said that God only delights in those who know and understand
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that He exercises loving-kindness, judgment, and righteousness in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: earth, and that such persons only are worthy of praise. (Jer. ix:23.) (25)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: As though God had said that, after the desolation of the city, He would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: require nothing special from the Jews beyond the natural law by which all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men are bound.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (26) The New Testament also confirms this view, for only moral doctrines are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therein taught, and the kingdom of heaven is promised as a reward, whereas
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ceremonial observances are not touched on by the Apostles, after they began
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to preach the Gospel to the Gentiles. (27) The Pharisees certainly continued
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to practise these rites after the destruction of the kingdom, but more with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a view of opposing the Christians than of pleasing God: for after the first
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destruction of the city, when they were led captive to Babylon, not being
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: then, so far as I am aware, split up into sects, they straightway neglected
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their rites, bid farewell to the Mosaic law, buried their national customs
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in oblivion as being plainly superfluous, and began to mingle with other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nations, as we may abundantly learn from Ezra and Nehemiah. (28) We cannot,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, doubt that they were no more bound by the law of Moses, after the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destruction of their kingdom, than they had been before it had been begun,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: while they were still living among other peoples before the exodus from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Egypt, and were subject to no special law beyond the natural law, and also,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doubtless, the law of the state in which they were living, in so far as it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was consonant with the Divine natural law.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (29) As to the fact that the patriarchs offered sacrifices, I think they did
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so for the purpose of stimulating their piety, for their minds had been
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accustomed from childhood to the idea of sacrifice, which we know had been
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: universal from the time of Enoch; and thus they found in sacrifice their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: most powerful incentive. (30) The patriarchs, then, did not sacrifice to God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at the bidding of a Divine right, or as taught by the basis of the Divine
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: law, but simply in accordance with the custom of the time; and, if in so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doing they followed any ordinance, it was simply the ordinance of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: country they were living in, by which (as we have seen before in the case of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Melchisedek) they were bound.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (31) I think that I have now given Scriptural authority for my view: it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remains to show why and how the ceremonial observances tended to preserve
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and confirm the Hebrew kingdom; and this I can very briefly do on grounds
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: universally accepted.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (32) The formation of society serves not only for defensive purposes, but is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also very useful, and, indeed, absolutely necessary, as rendering possible
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the division of labour. (33) If men did not render mutual assistance to each
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other, no one would have either the skill or the time to provide for his own
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sustenance and preservation: for all men are not equally apt for all work,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and no one would be capable of preparing all that he individually stood in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: need of. (34) Strength and time, I repeat, would fail, if every one had in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
