text: person to plough, to sow, to reap, to grind corn, to cook, to weave, to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stitch, and perform the other numerous functions required to keep life
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: going; to say nothing of the arts and sciences which are also entirely
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary to the perfection and blessedness of human nature. (35) We see
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that peoples living, in uncivilized barbarism lead a wretched and almost
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: animal life, and even they would not be able to acquire their few rude
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessaries without assisting one another to a certain extent.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (36) Now if men were so constituted by nature that they desired nothing but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what is designated by true reason, society would obviously have no need of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws: it would be sufficient to inculcate true moral doctrines; and men
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would freely, without hesitation, act in accordance with their true
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interests. (37) But human nature is framed in a different fashion: every
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one, indeed, seeks his own interest, but does not do so in accordance with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the dictates of sound reason, for most men's ideas of desirability and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: usefulness are guided by their fleshly instincts and emotions, which take no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought beyond the present and the immediate object. (38) Therefore, no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: society can exist without government, and force, and laws to restrain and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repress men's desires and immoderate impulses. (39) Still human nature will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not submit to absolute repression. (40) Violent governments, as Seneca says,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: never last long; the moderate governments endure. (41) So long as men act
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: simply from fear they act contrary to their inclinations, taking no thought
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for the advantages or necessity of their actions, but simply endeavouring to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: escape punishment or loss of life. (42) They must needs rejoice in any evil
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which befalls their ruler, even if it should involve themselves; and must
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: long for and bring about such evil by every means in their power. (43)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, men are especially intolerant of serving and being ruled by their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equals. (44) Lastly, it is exceedingly difficult to revoke liberties once
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: granted.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (45) From these considerations it follows, firstly, that authority should
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: either be vested in the hands of the whole state in common, so that everyone
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should be bound to serve, and yet not be in subjection to his equals; or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: else, if power be in the hands of a few, or one man, that one man should be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: something above average humanity, or should strive to get himself accepted
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as such. (46) Secondly, laws should in every government be so arranged that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people should be kept in bounds by the hope of some greatly desired good,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rather than by fear, for then everyone will do his duty willingly.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (47) Lastly, as obedience consists in acting at the bidding of external
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: authority, it would have no place in a state where the government is vested
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the whole people, and where laws are made by common consent. (48) In such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a society the people would remain free, whether the laws were added to or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: diminished, inasmuch as it would not be done on external authority, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their own free consent. (49) The reverse happens when the sovereign power is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vested in one man, for all act at his bidding; and, therefore, unless they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had been trained from the first to depend on the words of their ruler, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: latter would find it difficult, in case of need, to abrogate liberties once
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceded, and impose new laws.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (50) From these universal considerations, let us pass on to the kingdom of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Jews. (51) The Jews when they first came out of Egypt were not bound by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any national laws, and were therefore free to ratify any laws they liked, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to make new ones, and were at liberty to set up a government and occupy a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: territory wherever they chose. (52) However, they, were entirely unfit
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to frame a wise code of laws and to keep the sovereign power vested in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: community; they were all uncultivated and sunk in a wretched slavery,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore the sovereignty was bound to remain vested in the hands of one man
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who would rule the rest and keep them under constraint, make laws and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interpret them. (53) This sovereignty was easily retained by Moses,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because he surpassed the rest in virtue and persuaded the people of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact, proving it by many testimonies (see Exod. chap. xiv., last verse, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chap. xix:9). (54) He then, by the Divine virtue he possessed, made laws and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ordained them for the people, taking the greatest care that they should be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obeyed willingly and not through fear, being specially induced to adopt this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: course by the obstinate nature of the Jews, who would not have submitted to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be ruled solely by constraint; and also by the imminence of war, for it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: always better to inspire soldiers with a thirst for glory than to terrify
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them with threats; each man will then strive to distinguish himself
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by valour and courage, instead of merely trying to escape punishment. (55)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses, therefore, by his virtue and the Divine command, introduced a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religion, so that the people might do their duty from devotion rather than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear. (56) Further, he bound them over by benefits, and prophesied
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: many advantages in the future; nor were his laws very severe, as anyone may
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: see for himself, especially if he remarks the number of circumstances
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary in order to procure the conviction of an accused person.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (57) Lastly, in order that the people which could not govern itself should
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be entirely dependent on its ruler, he left nothing to the free choice of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: individuals (who had hitherto been slaves); the people could do nothing but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remember the law, and follow the ordinances laid down at the good pleasure
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of their ruler; they were not allowed to plough, to sow, to reap, nor even
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to eat; to clothe themselves, to shave, to rejoice, or in fact to do
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anything whatever as they liked, but were bound to follow the directions
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: given in the law; and not only this, but they were obliged to have marks on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their door-posts, on their hands, and between their eyes to admonish them to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perpetual obedience.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (58) This, then, was the object of the ceremonial law, that men should do
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing of their own free will, but should always act under external
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: authority, and should continually confess by their actions and thoughts that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they were not their own masters, but were entirely under the control of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: others.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (59) From all these considerations it is clearer than day that ceremonies
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have nothing to do with a state of blessedness, and that those mentioned in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Old Testament, i.e. the whole Mosaic Law, had reference merely to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: government of the Jews, and merely temporal advantages.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (60) As for the Christian rites, such as baptism, the Lord's Supper,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: festivals, public prayers, and any other observances which are, and always
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have been, common to all Christendom, if they were instituted by Christ or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: His Apostles (which is open to doubt), they were instituted as external
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: signs of the universal church, and not as having anything to do with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blessedness, or possessing any sanctity in themselves. (61) Therefore,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: though such ceremonies were not ordained for the sake of upholding a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: government, they were ordained for the preservation of a society, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accordingly he who lives alone is not bound by them: nay, those who live in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a country where the Christian religion is forbidden, are bound to abstain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from such rites, and can none the less live in a state of blessedness. (62)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: We have an example of this in Japan, where the Christian religion is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forbidden, and the Dutch who live there are enjoined by their East India
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Company not to practise any outward rites of religion. (63) I need not cite
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other examples, though it would be easy to prove my point from the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fundamental principles of the New Testament, and to adduce many confirmatory
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instances; but I pass on the more willingly, as I am anxious to proceed to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: my next proposition. (64) I will now, therefore, pass on to what I proposed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to treat of in the second part of this chapter, namely, what persons are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bound to believe in the narratives contained in Scripture, and how far they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are so bound. (65) Examining this question by the aid of natural reason, I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will proceed as follows.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (66) If anyone wishes to persuade his fellows for or against anything which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is not self-evident, he must deduce his contention from their admissions,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and convince them either by experience or by ratiocination; either by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appealing to facts of natural experience, or to self-evident intellectual
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: axioms. (67) Now unless the experience be of such a kind as to be clearly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and distinctly understood, though it may convince a man, it will not have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same effect on his mind and disperse the clouds of his doubt so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: completely as when the doctrine taught is deduced entirely from intellectual
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: axioms - that is, by the mere power of the understanding and logical order,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and this is especially the case in spiritual matters which have nothing to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: do with the senses.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (68) But the deduction of conclusions from general truths a priori, usually
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: requires a long chain of arguments, and, moreover, very great caution,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: acuteness, and self-restraint - qualities which are not often met with;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore people prefer to be taught by experience rather than deduce
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their conclusion from a few axioms, and set them out in logical order. (69)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Whence it follows, that if anyone wishes to teach a doctrine to a whole
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nation (not to speak of the whole human race), and to be understood by all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men in every particular, he will seek to support his teaching with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: experience, and will endeavour to suit his reasonings and the definitions of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his doctrines as far as possible to the understanding of the common people,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who form the majority of mankind, and he will not set them forth in logical
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sequence nor adduce the definitions which serve to establish them. (70)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Otherwise he writes only for the learned - that is, he will be understood by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only a small proportion of the human race.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (71) All Scripture was written primarily for an entire people, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: secondarily for the whole human race; therefore its contents must
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily be adapted as far as possible to the understanding of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: masses, and proved only by examples drawn from experience. (72) We will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explain ourselves more clearly. (73) The chief speculative doctrines taught
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in Scripture are the existence of God, or a Being Who made all things, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Who directs and sustains the world with consummate wisdom; furthermore, that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God takes the greatest thought for men, or such of them as live piously and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: honourably, while He punishes, with various penalties, those who do
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evil, separating them from the good. (74) All this is proved in Scripture
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entirely through experience-that is, through the narratives there related.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (75) No definitions of doctrine are given, but all the sayings and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reasonings are adapted to the understanding of the masses. (76) Although
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: experience can give no clear knowledge of these things, nor explain the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature of God, nor how He directs and sustains all things, it can
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nevertheless teach and enlighten men sufficiently to impress obedience
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and devotion on their minds.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (77) It is now, I think, sufficiently clear what persons are bound to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believe in the Scripture narratives, and in what degree they are so bound,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for it evidently follows from what has been said that the knowledge of and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: belief in them is particularly necessary to the masses whose intellect is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not capable of perceiving things clearly and distinctly. (78) Further, he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who denies them because he does not believe that God exists or takes thought
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for men and the world, may be accounted impious; but a man who is ignorant
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of them, and nevertheless knows by natural reason that God exists, as we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have said, and has a true plan of life, is altogether blessed - yes, more
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blessed than the common herd of believers, because besides true opinions he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possesses also a true and distinct conception. (79) Lastly, he who is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ignorant of the Scriptures and knows nothing by the light of reason, though
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he may not be impious or rebellious, is yet less than human and almost
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: brutal, having none of God's gifts.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (80) We must here remark that when we say that the knowledge of the sacred
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: narrative is particularly necessary to the masses, we do not mean the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge of absolutely all the narratives in the Bible, but only of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: principal ones, those which, taken by themselves, plainly display the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doctrine we have just stated, and have most effect over men's minds.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (81) If all the narratives in Scripture were necessary for the proof of this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doctrine, and if no conclusion could be drawn without the general
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consideration of every one of the histories contained in the sacred
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: writings, truly the conclusion and demonstration of such doctrine would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: overtask the understanding and strength not only of the masses, but of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: humanity; who is there who could give attention to all the narratives at
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: once, and to all the circumstances, and all the scraps of doctrine to be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: elicited from such a host of diverse histories? (82) I cannot believe that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the men who have left us the Bible as we have it were so abounding in talent
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that they attempted setting about such a method of demonstration, still less
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can I suppose that we cannot understand Scriptural doctrine till we have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: given heed to the quarrels of Isaac, the advice of Achitophel to Absalom,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the civil war between Jews and Israelites, and other similar chronicles; nor
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can I think that it was more difficult to teach such doctrine by means of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: history to the Jews of early times, the contemporaries of Moses, than it was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the contemporaries of Esdras. (83) But more will be said on this point
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hereafter, we may now only note that the masses are only bound to know those
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: histories which can most powerfully dispose their mind to obedience and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: devotion. (84) However, the masses are not sufficiently skilled to draw
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conclusions from what they read, they take more delight in the actual
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stories, and in the strange and unlooked-for issues of events than in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doctrines implied; therefore, besides reading these narratives, they are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: always in need of pastors or church ministers to explain them to their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: feeble intelligence.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (85) But not to wander from our point, let us conclude with what has been
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our principal object - namely, that the truth of narratives, be they what
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they may, has nothing to do with the Divine law, and serves for nothing
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: except in respect of doctrine, the sole element which makes one history
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: better than another. (86) The narratives in the Old and New Testaments
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: surpass profane history, and differ among themselves in merit simply by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason of the salutary doctrines which they inculcate. (87) Therefore, if a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man were to read the Scripture narratives believing the whole of them, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were to give no heed to the doctrines they contain, and make no amendment in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his life, he might employ himself just as profitably in reading the Koran
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or the poetic drama, or ordinary chronicles, with the attention usually
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: given to such writings; on the other hand, if a man is absolutely ignorant
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the Scriptures, and none the less has right opinions and a true
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: plan of life, he is absolutely blessed and truly possesses in himself the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: spirit of Christ.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (88) The Jews are of a directly contrary way of thinking, for they hold that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: true opinions and a true plan of life are of no service in attaining
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: blessedness, if their possessors have arrived at them by the light of reason
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only, and not like the documents prophetically revealed to Moses. (89)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Maimonides ventures openly to make this assertion: "Every man who takes to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: heart the seven precepts and diligently follows them, is counted with the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pious among the nation, and an heir of the world to come; that is to say, if
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he takes to heart and follows them because God ordained them in the law, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revealed them to us by Moses, because they were of aforetime precepts to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sons of Noah: but he who follows them as led thereto by reason, is not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: counted as a dweller among the pious or among the wise of the nations." (90)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Such are the words Of Maimonides, to which R. Joseph, the son of Shem Job,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adds in his book which he calls "Kebod Elohim, or God's Glory," that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: although Aristotle (whom he considers to have written the best ethics and to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be above everyone else) has not omitted anything that concerns
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: true ethics, and which he has adopted in his own book, carefully following
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the lines laid down, yet this was not able to suffice for his salvation,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inasmuch as he embraced his doctrines in accordance with the dictates of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason and not as Divine documents prophetically revealed.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (91) However, that these are mere figments, and are not supported by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scriptural authority will, I think, be sufficiently evident to the attentive
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reader, so that an examination of the theory will be sufficient for its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: refutation. (92) It is not my purpose here to refute the assertions of those
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who assert that the natural light of reason can teach nothing, of any value
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning the true way of salvation. (93) People who lay no claims to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason for themselves, are not able to prove by reason this their assertion;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and if they hawk about something superior to reason, it is a mere figment,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and far below reason, as their general method of life sufficiently shows.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (94) But there is no need to dwell upon such persons. (95) I will merely add
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that we can only judge of a man by his works. (96) If a man abounds in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fruits of the Spirit, charity, joy, peace, long-suffering, kindness,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: goodness, faith, gentleness, chastity, against which, as Paul says
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Gal. v:22), there is no law, such an one, whether he be taught by reason
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only or by the Scripture only, has been in very truth taught by God, and is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: altogether blessed. (97) Thus have I said all that I undertook to say
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning Divine law.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Chapter I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 1. (1) The word naw-vee', Strong:5030, is rightly interpreted
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by Rabbi Salomon Jarchi, but the sense is hardly caught by Aben Ezra, who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was not so good a Hebraist. (2) We must also remark that this Hebrew word
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for prophecy has a universal meaning and embraces all kinds of prophecy. (3)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Other terms are more special, and denote this or that sort of prophecy,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as I believe is well known to the learned.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 2. (1) "Although, ordinary knowledge is Divine, its professors
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be called prophets." That is, interpreters of God. (2) For he alone
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is an interpreter of God, who interprets the decrees which God has revealed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to him, to others who have not received such revelation, and whose belief,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, rests merely on the prophet's authority and the confidence
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reposed in him. (3) If it were otherwise, and all who listen to prophets
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: became prophets themselves, as all who listen to philosophers become
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: philosophers, a prophet would no longer be the interpreter of Divine
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: decrees, inasmuch as his hearers would know the truth, not on the authority
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the prophet, but by means of actual Divine revelation and inward
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: testimony. (4) Thus the sovereign powers are the interpreters of their own
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rights of sway, because these are defended only by their authority and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: supported by their testimony.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 3. (1) "Prophets were endowed with a peculiar and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: extraordinary power." (2) Though some men enjoy gifts which nature has not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bestowed on their fellows, they are not said to surpass the bounds of human
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, unless their special qualities are such as cannot be said to be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deducible from the definition of human nature. (3) For instance, a giant is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a rarity, but still human. (4) The gift of composing poetry extempore is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: given to very few, yet it is human. (5) The same may, therefore, be said of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the faculty possessed by some of imagining things as vividly as though they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: saw them before them, and this not while asleep, but while awake. (6) But if
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anyone could be found who possessed other means and other foundations for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: knowledge, he might be said to transcend the limits of human nature.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1

text: Endnote 4. (1) In Gen. xv. it is written that God promised Abraham to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: protect him, and to grant him ample rewards. (2) Abraham answered that he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: could expect nothing which could be of any value to him, as he was childless
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and well stricken in years.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Endnote 5. (1) That a keeping of the commandments of the old Testament
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 1
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is not sufficient for eternal life, appears from Mark x:21.
